I tried everything to get some performance out of it, but my pictures always ended up looking bland and un-interesting, Also had alot of focusing problems, my old Kodak shot much sharper pics.  So on to the next camera.  Out went the Panny and in came the much more expensive Sony HX9v.  was sure this camera was the answer to all my problems.  It has a 16x Zoom, 1080p at 60fps video, Gps, 920,000 dot screen.  This camera has some great video!  Rivals many higher end camcorders, also has the best image stabilization I've ever seen.  Does pretty good video in low-light too.  Just one minor HUGE problem, the actual pictures are weak.  Really weak.  Every once in a while you might accidently get a picture that is almost decent, but that is rare.  The file sizes of these pics are tiny (no way they are true 16mp shots).  The pics are also off color, soft, and the de-focus feature I was so excited about is just a gimmick that almost never works correctly.  Also forget doing anything creative with this camera, their are NO built in filters besides plain black and white, and a very harsh looking sepia.  So why do I still have it?  it makes a decent pocket camcorder with a 16x zoom.  So with that all out of the way, I wanted something affordable that took really good pictures and I wanted it to be fun, because I've always wanted to do some creative street shooting.  Ran into a deal on the Olympus E-PL1 for $199.  Couldn't beleive this was about a $600 camera less then 2 years ago.  SO I looked up all the professional and consumer reviews I could find.  Learned why I should buy it, and why I shouldn't.  The mass majority of the reviews were favorable so I decided to give it a try. So glad I did, Best camera I've ever owned.  Learn to use the settings and your pics will be stunning.  That huge sensor makes a big difference over your average point and shoots.  I've shot animals, landmarks, lakes, rustic looking artistic shots.  Some of the photos look so good I can't believe I've shot them.  No photoshopping needed.  Comes with 6 built in art filters and damn do they work well.  Pin-hole, soft focus, and film grain are my favorites.  I also bought a cheap plastic Holga lens off ebay ($15) to really get some amazing vintage shots.  Get alot of compliments from friends and family on many shots. They also can't beleive what I paid, they think I'm using some kind of high priced rig. Camera offers pretty speedy shooting too.  Just make sure to have a fast SD card and to update the firmware.  720p video at 30 fps actually works pretty well.  I bought this camera for pictures so having decent HD video is just a bonus.  I actually enjoy taking pictures again thanks to the E-PL1.

Reviews.Title: Picture quality to price ratio is far off the scale on this one
Reviews.Author: Joseph Ritch
Reviews.Content: First off, when I grabbed this one it was on a crazy price cut.  Here's the whole story though:I started off with a Panasonic Lumix DMC-GFKK3 kit.  It was okay, kinda nice to have a touchscreen for certain things; a burden for others.  The Panasonic cost me around $400 USD, which I would have been more than happy to pay except that the picture quality was so subpar it really gave me a heap big buyer's remorse.  Luckily, the place I purchased it at (not Amazon) has a decent return policy. I ended up taking it back right after I saw the Pen at it's quite reasonable price.The PEN arrived quickly with Prime, and as soon as I got it out and slapped an SD card into it, I snapped a few shots and sighed a huge sigh of relief.  The picture quality was exactly what I was expecting it to be, and far superior to that of the Lumix. I had spent hours playing with the Lumix to ensure picture quality settings and video settings were set up properly to no avail - the Pen is far superior in picture quality, hands down.Though the PEN lacks in the department of crazy features (like touchscreen and 3D capability), it excels in picture quality and (IMO) user-interface.  Olympus glass (lenses) are always pretty great too, though this kit came with an L series (plastic lens mount instead of metal) kit lens (which is fine for the price), the quality of the glass itself is still great.I paired this camera up with a compatible Eye-Fi card and it's been great so far!  If you can get a good price on this camera, I would say shoot for it.  It's a very practical for an amateur photographer and more portable than an SLR while sacrificing only a few SLR features that are not missed when the price is considered.

Reviews.Title: SLR Quality in a Portable Package
Reviews.Author: JAL "JAL"
Reviews.Content: I have not been this excited about a camera since the evolution of compact 35mm film cameras.  In real life, I found myself leaving my full frame DSLR and 2 1/4 inch square reflex camera at home and packing a compact waterproof digital camera on trips. I got the pictures, but missed the quality images. This camera is small and light enough to take anywhere and the images are good enough for 16X20 prints. This may be due to the large size of the sensors. The in camera processing is good enough to shoot in jpeg, not raw, simplifying post image processing.  I use a binocular strap to carry this camera over my shoulder so that I do not feel like a tourist. This is reminiscent to me of hiding a 35mm rangefinder. The lens structure does wobble at telephoto focal lengths, but I mostly take images at wide angles of view. The LCD screen is fine for me, except in bright sunlight where the EVF may be a good addition. Buyers should know that this lens has a plastic lens mount so you are NOT getting the metal mount seen with the ED lens. This kit lens is the L ED lens. The camera has in camera image stabilization and dust control. Focusing speed is adequate outdoors.The built in pop up flash is a nice feature for occasional flash photography and fill.I am also shooting with the Lumix 20mm f1.7 pancake lens. I am happy with the images from this lens, but the Olympus does NOT support in camera lens aberration correction for this lens as seen when this lens is used on a Lumix micro 4/3 camera. Actually I don't think this is a big deal. The PL1 with this lens fits nicely in my jacket pocket, so no need to leave it at home. The lens is fast enough for available light, but the focusing is, IMHO, slow indoors. I am getting better pictures using available light in the Program Mode, choosing the ISO and using center focus only. So I focus in the center, and then holding my finger in position, reframe and then press my finger down fully to shoot. No question that I get better images with a full frame DSLR and 35mm f1.4 lens in available indoor light, but we are comparing apples and oranges here.I tend to hit the movie record button accidentally, but I have now trained my errant finger to avoid this button.I was surprised by the ease of taking indoor movies with this camera. The movies are in AVI format and it IS possible to get iMovie on the Mac to export the movie to .mv4 and iDVD to burn the .mv4 to DVD that can be opened by a standard stand alone DVD player. (Note that you can just rename .mv4 files to .mp4 since the encoding is identical. Some programs that do not recognize .mv4 will recognize the same file as .mp4. Go figure.)The battery charger uses a separate AC cord and is bulky for traveling. I am now using a compact battery charger with a built in AC plug for traveling.This sort of reminds me of fishing. You cannot catch fish if your hook is not in the water and you cannot take great pictures if you leave your camera at home.Have fun,JAL

Reviews.Title: Best Camera for the money
Reviews.Author: Ali Roustai
Reviews.Content: I recently bought this camera and I am very happy with it even tough this camera was designed in 2009. This is my initial review.Pros:Excellent picture quality especially with Olympus Macro 50 mm lens.Even the kid lens is very sharp.Very little barrel distortionIntuitive commands.Full manual controls and RAW.Destroys all point and shoot cameras that I have had form past till present (we are 2012 now)Excellent value for the priceConsWish it had full HD videoIt's easy to accidentally press the video record button.Shutter speed of 1/2000 not fast enough for daylight if you are using a lens that can go below an f of 2.8The Olympus adapter is expensive and auto-focus is slower when using the adapterConclusionI like the pictures from this camera using the the 50 mm macro better that the ones from my Canon 40 D with the 50 f 1.4 lens

Reviews.Title: Best JPEG Camera Ever!
Reviews.Author: Bob Dylan Fan
Reviews.Content: If you want the best SLR camera on the planet, this might not be it.There are other cameras that will shoot faster, in lower light, with higher resolution, etc...Still, the E-PL1 can hold its own against the best SLR cameras, certainly far better than any compact cameras in regards to approaching the best SLR quality.However, if you want to squeeze everything out of the best SLR cameras, you need to shoot raw and be prepared to do alot of post-processing.On the other hand, this little gem will squeeze everything out of its capabilities directly into JPEG, so your out of camera pictures are simply outstanding.  There is no reason to shoot raw.So, for real world shooting, especially for family vacations, travel, etc..., this camera is impossible to beat.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I am an Olympus and Canon DSLR user who wanted a lightweight alternative to carrying a heavy DSLR all of the time. I have a good-quality Point & Shoot, but I'm spoiled by the picture quality of DSLRs and wanted something small that could create similar images.  I hesitated in buying this camera, though, because I was weary of only having an LCD screen.  I finally gave in to temptation when I got a good deal on the camera and an addition 40-150 lens.That being said- this camera is awesome.  The picture quality is amazing.  Even in indoor-lighting situations the picture quality is sharp and crisp.  I actually like its  picture quality over both my Canon and Olympus DSLRs for indoor situations without a flash.I also like that while it's small, it still has enough size and weight that it balances out the weight of the lenses.  I've tried some lightweight superzooms and PEN-style competitors.  They are so lightweight that the heavier lens throws off the balance and make it hard to get a steady shot.  This camera however has enough weight to balance the lens- easing my concerns about not having a view finder.I strongly recommend this camera for anyone wanting to move up from a point-and-shoot or DSLR users who are looking for a smaller alternative that still has the quality of a DSLR camera.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic!
Reviews.Author: K. Morse
Reviews.Content: As an advanced amateur photographer, this camera is just what I was looking for!  Friendly enough to allow anyone to point and shoot, but advanced enough to allow great pictures to be taken by someone who knows what they're doing.I've been shooting for the last few weeks with both the stock 14-42mm zuiko and the panasonic 20mm.  For most situations, the zuiko works well enough, but in low light it's just not fast enough to avoid some noise.  Shooting with the 20mm is a dream, however!  It's fast in low light and produces amazing bokeh in brighter situations effortlessly.I love the retro feel of the camera and the fact that it's just compact enough to be comfortable for carrying around while traveling, hiking etc.  All in all, it's a very satisfying camera to shoot with!The only minor gripes I have are the following:- Lack of viewfinder- Slightly dull, washed out LCD (although this can be corrected somewhat by adjusting it via the menus)- Inconsistent auto focus performance in low light (easy to correct with a little manual adjustment)- Poor stock battery life (search ebay for 1800mAh+ replacements - they make all the difference in the world!)I can live with these flaws in light of the overall value and picture quality.  This camera is not absolutely perfect, but it is absolutely great!

Reviews.Title: Very good entry to the micro-4/3rds system
Reviews.Author: Michael J. Edelman
Reviews.Content: I've been carrying Nikon SLRs since the 1970s, starting with an EM-1 and working through several AEs, FMs, F2s, an F3, a D70 and finally a D80. Along the way I've accumulated a lot of older Nikon lenses and a few newer autofocus ones and a few flash units. But when I go out to shoot these days, I rarely take the D80 out. Instead, I take an advanced compact Lumix camera I picked up a year ago. It has higher resolution than the D80, and it's a lot handier. It occurred to me that the only real justification I had for keeping the SLRs was that I could use them with non-standard lenses, like pinhole lenses or my telescopes. But that doesn't have to lock you in to DSLRs anymore.All the major camera makers are coming out with a line of mirror less interchangeable lens cameras. Nikon has a new system, but it's not compatible with their old lens mount. That convinced me to look around a bit to see what else was on the market. Sony has a system that's been getting some acclaim, and Canon has a brand new system. But what what caught my eye was the "micro 4/3rds" standard cameras from Olympus and Panasonic. Two companies making lenses and bodies gives you some competition, and the cameras are fully compatible (with the proper adapter)  with the standard 4/3rds lenses made for larger DSLRs.I decided to try the system by just dipping a toe in, as it were, and ordered an Olympus PEN E-PL1. I didn't order the lens at first; instead, I ordered a handful of inexpensive adapters for T-threaded lenses, C-mount (cinema) lenses and manual Nikon lenses, so I could evaluate the camera with what I had on hand, and see how well it would adapt with things like telescope use. It only took me a day for fooling around to decided to go ahead and order the matching 14-42 lens as well.The Olympus E-PL1 is the entry model in Olympus' line of micro 4/3rds cameras, lacking some of the knobs and features of the E-PL2 and E-PL3. It doesn't lack in quality, however, and it can do things my Nikon D80 couldn't do, like autoexposure with an older, manual Nikon lens. I haven't attached it to my Questar telescope yet, but I'm looking forward to trying it. At a fraction of the weight of the D80 (and the F3 I used before that), the E-PL1 will be much easier to use with the Q. The lighter weight also means I probably won't need a counterweight.I'm happy enough with this camera that I decided to go ahead and pack all my Nikon digital gear and send it off to KEH for sale. I'm keeping my best older lenses, as they don't have a lot of resale value, and I think a lot of them will work great with the Oly- the 55/1.4 will be a great low light lens, I'll continue to use the Micro-Nikkor 55mm for nature photography, and the 300/4.5 should be an interesting one to try. Are the current cop of micro-4/3rds cameras as good as the top of the line, full frame DSLRs? No, but then, they don't cost $4,000, either. If you're thinking of buying one of the entry-level DSLRs like the D40 or similar Canons I suspect you'd be far better off with a micro 4/3rds camera.I'm pleased enough with this camera that I'm thinking about taking the cash from the sale of my Nikon gear and getting a second body, and perhaps a fixed wide angle lens, or a telephoto. Leading contender right now is the Panasonic Lumix DMC-GX1 16 MP Micro 4/3 Compact System Camera with 3-Inch LCD Touch Screen Body Only (Black), but I may go a bit simpler and buy a used DMC-GF1 if I can find a good deal.One added thought: If you're going to go to the trouble (and expense) of using a M43 or DSLR, for goodness sake, shoot in RAW mode! Yes, it takes up more space on your SD card than shooting in JPG, but so what? Memory is cheap today. You can get a good 16GB card for $16-20 that will hold more than a thousand images shooting in RAW at your largest image size. Shooting in JPG you lose resolution AND color information. If you wonder why your photos taken with your new camera don't have any more snap than those taken with your $120 point and shoot, switch to RAW mode and see the difference.

Reviews.Title: Stunning Photos
Reviews.Author: Big-Z
Reviews.Content: I have owned 32 digital cameras since 1992, and I must say the EPL1 is one of my favorites. Currently I own the Pentax K-5, Sony NEX3, and this EPL1. I love the look of it, the feel in my large hands, and most of all, the quality of pictures in most lighting situations. The lenses for it are really good, including the 14-42 that comes with it. I have also added the Zuiko 9-18mm f/4.0-5.6 ED Zoom Lens with adapter. I bought both the EPL1 and the 9-18 lens as supposed factory demos. Both have looked and worked like brand new. I love the combination for scenic shots. Since I paid so little for the camera with the 14-42 lens (less than most point and shoots), it would take a great deal of negatives for me to be disappointed, but I can say that if I had paid full price for this camera, lens combo, it would still be a great camera. The larger sensor makes a big difference in image quality and the image quality with this cam is consistent corner to corner. I never pick up my NEX-3 any longer even though it is a great camera. I always seem to reach for my EPL1, unless I want the best shot possible in very low light; then I grab my K5.

Reviews.Title: Great bridge camera
Reviews.Author: John of Jax
Reviews.Content: The Olympus Pen E-PL1 is an excellent bridge camera. This camera fits my need to move from point and shoot cameras to the interchangeable lens (ILC) world. I needed to take photos of jewelry to post online and was not pleased with the photos from my new 16MP point and shoot camera. I needed a camera I could manually focus and get great closeup shots. I did a lot of research and was reluctant to spend $500 and more for a single purpose camera. I, like most other shoppers, was focused on MP size thinking that would give me the quality photos I needed. Some of the reviews I've read mentioned larger MP size did not necessarily mean better photos. I had discounted the four-third cameras because most topped out at 12MP. I learned a great deal about the technology at four-thirds.org and decided to take a chance on the Olympus PEN E-PL1.I have been extremely pleased with the photos from this camera. The quality of the photos surpass those of my 16MP P&S; camera. The colors are as true as I've seen. My jewelry photos are coming out great. It is as easy to use as a point & shoot, but is much more capable. The iAuto setting is as simple as it gets, but as I learn more I am able to take advantage of the additional settings and take some really creative shots. This camera has opened a whole new world of photography beyond that for which it was originally purchased.This has been one of the best buys I have made in a long time and at less than $300 is a terrific bargain! The size of this camera is a plus. It is not much larger than a point and shoot camera, so I think most people would be more likely to take this camera vs a large DSLR camera.The only con is the price for additional lens. But with adapters you can use any of hundreds of lens out there. I was able to get a used 50mm f1.8 OM Olympus lens for $25 and an adapter for $23 and I now get great portrait photos with a nice soft background. The only trade-off is you must focus manually, but that is an easy compromise for the low price of a legacy lens.I recommend this camera if you want to move up from P&S; cameras at a low cost.

Reviews.Title: Great time to get into M4/3rd with this camera
Reviews.Author: Charles "Charles"
Reviews.Content: Until recently, I always thought of myself as a Nikon/Canon DSLR kind of guy. But after reevaluating my photographic priorities, I rolled the dice and went EPL1.This is one fun camera. Amazing Jpegs--forget RAW (embarrassed to admit it), the jpegs on this are so beautiful--no need to post process. And the art filters are so much fun (slowness is there, but still usable). My old manual film lenses have new life with this camera.I find i reach for this more than my trusty D90.Don't want to go on and on here. In summary this is art in a box. And at $280, this is a steal.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera for the price.
Reviews.Author: Daniel Watson
Reviews.Content: After years of owning DSLRs such as the Nikon D200 and Canon Rebel XSI I can honestly say that the IQ of this camera is second to none.  High ISO and color production is actually better than my former SLRs.  The JPEGs from the EPL-1 are stunning to say the very least and after years of shooting RAW I am glad to spend more time out shooting and less time behind a computer trying to get things right.  The menu system is much better than my former EP1 and auto focus is greatly improved to the point where it leaves very little to be desire.  Is this camera good enough to replace your SLR with, yes it is.

Reviews.Title: Faster than you think!
Reviews.Author: Barry Pehlman
Reviews.Content: The E-PL1 is a reasonably priced alternative to the E-P2 Pen series, but with a small, pop-up flash.  It's priced approximately $250-300 below the cost of an EP-2 as is a Panasonic GF1.  The main differences are the E-P1's stainless steel construction, although the E-PL1 feels quite solid to me, EPL's 1/2000th sec. shutter speed compared to 1/4000th, a few less ART filters (meh), and arguably a less intuitive menu... if you that's the place you like to hang out a lot.Olympus recently released a 1.1 firmware update for all Pen series cameras to increase AF speed.  The difference now between the ever-compared Panasonic GF1 (.47) and the EP series (.7) amounts to about 1/5th of a second, nothing to complain about and imperceptible in reality.  In the film days this shutter lag time is about the same difference as a "faster" Leica M6 rangefinder and a pro level SLR, a fact that wasn't enough to stop people from buying SLRs. Even if you are so fine-tuned to sense a AF speed difference, you can always depress the shutter half-way first thus resulting in no shutter lag... OR manually focus... OR zone focus which is even faster.  Photographers should know, or at least learn how to go to plan B or C when needed.  The E-PL1 is a wonderful technical achievement dumbed down in a few areas, but still generally very sophisticated for the casual user. It is not a replacement for a DSLR, nor was it intended to shoot sports.When you are in the Panasonic Lumix GF1 camp it's all about AF speed.  Once that discussion is silenced most GFers fail to mention the E-PL1's in-body IS, nicer colors, a much better EVF, smoother manual focusing, a more quiet AF focus for HD audio, a stereo mike accessory, or better subject tracking. The Panny 20 f1.7 pancake is great, but it doesn't have IS thus your movies and arms-length shots, especially in low light, have the tendency to be slightly blurred.As for Lori Gruden comments from Cnet:  She seems to regularly give mediocre grades to the same highly reviewed cameras by other professional testers, even in opposition to those consumers who actually use the product she's nitpicking.  I believe she commented that Olympus should have got the E-PL1 "right" before it was released, not relying on firmware to fix their mistakes.  If that was the case Microsoft Windows, GPS devices, in fact all improvements to existing products would have to be purchased new again... sort of like the expensive way Apple markets it's products.Anyway, I like the E-PL1. It sure beats hauling the FF DSLR/lenses all over for casual photography. The 17 f2.8 pancake is very nice.  The kit lens is decent, but has a plastic mount.  I guess you shouldn't expect too much because it's included kit price works out to around $50 if you bought the body separately.  I will be purchasing a VF2 electronic viewfinder, and a 14-150mm MFT lens ($600) when it is released this summer.

Reviews.Title: Love it now, but I hated it for a while.
Reviews.Author: Hike & Bike
Reviews.Content: I had packed this camera up 3 times to send it back.  I'm glad I didn't.  I honestly haven't had so much fun or freedom with a camera, but getting to that point wasn't easy for me.I've owned my fair share of DSLR cameras and figured it would be an easy conversion.  It wasn't.  I was frustrated and I agree with the reviewer who cautions about being honest with your priorities.  I think I was expecting too much.  This camera won't do everything, but it does a lot.  There are a lot of features that I love.  I especially like the screen magnification on manual focus, GENIUS!I think this camera was mis-represented as a camera for the masses and not so much for the serious photographer.  I have taken more pleasing travel, fine art, and portrait images than I have in a long time.  Perhaps its just because the camera goes with me everywhere and I'm shooting way more.I was a bit disappointed with the kit lens.  Optically its fine, however there is no lens shade and its difficult to attach filters.  I purchased a used Panasonic Lumix 14-45 because it addresses those issues.  As an added benefit the Lumix has in-lens stabilization which I find superior to the in-camera stabilization when using the camera for video.  If I'm using the kit lens for video, I just turn off the stabilization.Lastly, for Lightroom users, I was frustrated with developing the RAW files in LR3.  After some experimenting I found that if I re-set my preferences to default the blacks to zero it made a tremendous difference when there are dark areas.  I found that the dark areas tended to block up badly with the previous default of 5 for the blacks.  I also made custom tone curves which began with the medium and strong contrast curves.  I modified both curves by lifting the left most point (the on in the bottom corner) just a tiny bit up the vertical axis.  These also make a huge difference in preventing the blacks from blocking up.Enjoy the PEN, its awesome.  Be patient and you'll love it.

Reviews.Title: A good first step into the world of Micro-Four-Thirds photography.
Reviews.Author: KarKrash81 "KarKrash81"
Reviews.Content: This was my first micro-four-thirds camera, and my first "serious" camera. My previous photography experience had been limited to a variety of cell phones and an aging Canon S2 IS. To say that this upgrade was somewhat of a revelation would be an understatement. Even with the kit lens, the quality of the photos was light-years ahead of my previous cameras. After approximately 15,000 pictures I sold it and moved up to the E-P3 and just recently purchased the OMD.PROS:While the sensor and capabilities of the E-PL1 have been surpassed by newer micro-four-thirds cameras, I was very pleased with the output of this camera. JPG's are punchy and vibrant without looking fake. I was comfortable shooting up to ISO 1600 for low light shots. I also own an E-P3 and prefer the noise profile of this camera.The burst rate of 3 frames per second is good for a camera of this class (and for 2010). Paired with some high quality lenses, the photos you can produce from this camera can be stunning. I have used it extensively with the Panasonic 20mm f1.7 and Panasonic-Leica 25mm f1.4 lenses. The camera almost becomes a brand new device when you add some good glass. Lenses like this will provide some fun depth-of-field (not as much as larger format sensors), and hugely improved low-light capabilities.From an aesthetic point of view the camera exudes retro charm when viewed from the front. The hand grip is deep enough and makes holding the camera much more manageable.The on-board flash is handy if you need one. I rarely use it, but the ability to turn the flash upwards for bounce-flashes is handy.Battery Life-Even though the official battery life rating is 330 shots, I could easily get 600 shots per charge. I never use the flash and don't let the camera sit idle. Of course, using the flash and letting the camera stay on when not in use will probably get you closer to the official rating.The camera is full of settings, options, and features. Even after a year of using the E-PL1, I didn't touch everything. The art filters are fun, though I rarely used them. I relegated 90% of my usage to the S and A modes.CONS:Even though the front of the camera exhibits a retro (albeit boxy) design, the rear of the camera feels very cheap. The buttons seem flimsy and the recessed screen is low res.At the time, I was happy with the performance of the kit lens, but now, after owning half a dozen native lenses, I feel that the first-generation kit lens for the Olympus MFT cameras is their worst lens by far. First, the mount is plastic and after a lot of usage the lens will wobble a tiny bit in the mount. The focusing elements are not internal and during video recording, the focusing can easily be heard. At certain shutter speeds (160-200) it seems that the shutter causes the elements to vibrate causing some small amounts of blur. I highly recommend picking up the newer kit lens sold with the E-PL2, E-PM1, E-PL3, or E-P3 over this kit lens.The other major negative concerning this camera are the controls. Due to the lack of any dials, quickly changing settings can be somewhat cumbersome and even after using the camera for a year I still missed shots because I couldn't change key settings quick enough.Some may find the top shutter speed (1/2000) limiting. If you have a fast lens and want to use it in sunlight, this might be an issue, but even 1/4000 is often too slow for fast lenses. I would recommend an ND filter instead.SUMMARY:A fun camera that can produce quality images with good glass. I find the controls to be cumbersome and the feel of the camera to be cheap, but at such low prices it's hard to argue with the results.

Reviews.Title: I LOVE this camera!
Reviews.Author: Lauren
Reviews.Content: First of all, let me start out by saying that I've always been interested in photography, and I used to own a DSLR. Unfortunately, I never had the time or the subjects to really take the time to learn all the aspects of the camera and would just rely on my point and shoot. When I heard about this camera, I loved the idea because the options of a DSLR were there, but didnt need to be used.SO, since I am not used to using a DSLR, this camera is perfect for me. I can understand how this camera may be frustrating to one who is versed in using a DSLR, but for those people who want more than a point and shoot but don't want to make the full commitment to a DSLR, this camera is perfect. I took a few test shots of nothing around my room and even those pictures came out wonderful. I really recommend this camera for someone who is too afraid to try the DSLR.The only con is that other lenses are expensive, about as much as the camera. It is a setback because I would like to take different types of shots that may require different lenses. But this review is for this camera, not other things, which is why I kept the rating at 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Little camera, great options
Reviews.Author: E Karr
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as a Fathers Day gift.  What a great product. I had 4 lenses from Topcon cameras I own.  With a cheap adaptor I am able to use all of them.  You get all the capability of a point and shoot(only a little bigger) with all the power of a DSLR. Highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great addition
Reviews.Author: John Murdock
Reviews.Content: First impressions.  I have been using Olympus products for a long time.  I understand that they are not Nikons or canons, but I think you get more from your Olympus.  They feel good in your hand, they make you want to use them.  I still have my old OM 4.  I still use my "old" glass.  I entered the digital market with a Sony  Cybershot.  Never fulfilled my desires to take pictures.  I bought a second Sony Cybershot and it was still just a camera.  I finally found what I was looking for an early Dslr.  I could have chose a Nikon or a Canon, family members owned them at the time, but i had to be different, I purchased an Olympus E-500 two lenses kit.  I also purchased 3 adapters, one for OM lenses, and Canon and Nikon.  I am still using my E-500 and pictures come out great, as long as you know the cameras limitations.  Now why did I buy, the EPL-1, for fun.  At under $300.00 it isnt cheap but its not expensive.  Olympus lenses are top notch for the price.  Do I miss the viewfinder, you bet.  But I still have my old E-500 and now its new baby brother.  Each has its place, but each makes me want to take pictures.  Is it the best camera in its class, I don't know? Probably not, but is it a better camera than I am a photographer, YUP.  Try one, it will just make you want to take pictures.  You won't be afraid to break it, use it and above all its an Olympus.  Once you own one you will understand.

Reviews.Title: This is not a point and shoot
Reviews.Author: fair review
Reviews.Content: Although this can be a really good point and shoot camera, if the owner spends time getting familiar with it, it can really open up significant photographic opportunities that one wouldn't expect a point and shoot to be capable of. Even though the unit is not much bigger than some point and shoots, the larger-format four-thirds sensor produces images that even the best point and shoots may have to work hard to match, and the numerous control options can provide a level of customization to match mid-range DSLRs.One drawback may be that Olympus hasn't developed too many lenses for their micro four-thirds line. While Panasonic has a number of lenses for their micro four-thirds line that will fit this camera, they have their IS mechanism in the lenses instead of the body like Olympus, which may explain what appears to he higher prices for Panasonic lenses.While this camera has a built-in pop-up flash, unlike some of the other Olympus micro four-thirds cameras, it appears this camera will work with older Olympus dedicated flashes. For those who own these older flash units, it may open up a whole new set of possibilities. Of course, if someone wanted to use the camera's built-in flash unit to trigger remote flash units, which is not something one would find in many point and shoots, they can buy the newer R-spec Olympus flashes.In conclusion, this camera can be a compelling value for specific shooters, particularly those who don't mind getting used lenses on Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Beware the cost of lenses and accessories
Reviews.Author: sub_c
Reviews.Content: Chances are if you bought an E-PL1, you're a bit more enthusiastic about photography than the average point-and-shooter. I bought the PEN E-PL1 not just for its compact performance, but also for its price. As I used my E-PL1 and in the process learned a bit more about photography, I found that it needs more in order to achieve the image I desire. However, lenses and additional accessories are expensive! Of course, you don't have to purchase these items, but you'll miss out on the true capabilities of the E-PL1 and on some awesome pictures.The included kit lens simply cannot give you the shallow DOF that you need for the blurred background effect or "bokeh," and the fast shutter speeds that you can achieve with wider aperture. However, a lens like the popular Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 costs more than than E-PL1! (But I guess that's true of most m4/3 systems)Electronic viewfinders are also quite expensive. Composition is just not the same with the LCD screen, especially when it's too bright outside and you can't even see it properly. Looking through the viewfinder also has the added benefit of stabilizing the camera as you hold it against your head.External flash isn't as big a deal. With a little ingenuity, you can DIY a diffuser, which would make the pop-up flash more useful. However, if you want to get creative with your photographs, you'll find yourself needing an external flash unit, which are also expensive.I rate the E-PL1 body four stars; five if the In-body Image Stabilization actually worked or if the controls were more user-friendly. But a good photograph requires more than just a good body.

Reviews.Title: Professional photos in natural light
Reviews.Author: natmpetty
Reviews.Content: First of all, I am not a professional photographer. I was looking for a camera that was easy to use but delivered professional type photos. I reviewed countless cameras before I made a decision. I ended up going with this one. I function mainly in the auto setting. The photos in natural light are stunning. The photos in low light are not that great however I'm sure if I knew what I was doing I could tweak it and they would be fine. Last night at my Christmas party I used the soft light setting and it really made a difference in the photos. They are gorgeous. If you love cool- looking photography but don't want to spend a whole lot of time studying the art of photography then this is the camera for you. I do, however know of a professional photographer that uses this camera as her backup camera since it is so light. She shoots weddings with it. If you are someone who knows a lot about photography then I bet you could really do something with this camera... but if you're not then you will get some great shots, too. One thing I need to mention is that if you're looking for like sports or action shots then I would pass this one up. It is mainly for portraits I think. It has a continuous mode but the pictures aren't as clear. I was looking for a camera for portrait type photos so I believe I made the best decision for me.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Pictures - Slight Learning Curve
Reviews.Author: S. Terry
Reviews.Content: I bought the E-PL1 a few weeks ago.  Out of the box experience was so-so.  There is a decent learning curve to figure out the camera and the best picture taking experience.  Once I figured out the camera  I have really grown to enjoy it.  It takes great pictures and I really enjoy the portability factor.  I also bought he 20mm Panasonic pancake lens and the combination E-PL1/20mm lens is fantastic.  I can easily put it into my cargo shorts pocket.  I took it to Disneyland and it was a lot of fun to use.  The video quality is great but is a bit shaky, but again, I need to learn how to shoot better video.  This is not an inexpensive purchase, but it does exactly what I was looking for:  Small package with DSLR quality.  I would definitely recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Zero Trade-Off for Portability
Reviews.Author: road warrior "mrgondo"
Reviews.Content: Finally, Olympus has delivered on the promise of a full-featured high-performance dslr-like digital camera that is truly portable and retains the controls and flexibility of a full-sized heavy dslr. Being able to travel without the bulk and weight of a full size dslr bag and accessory lenses is the biggest advantage to getting this camera. You can now take it with you and and your travel weight is well under 5 LBS with the camera, battery, and 2 lenses.The sensor and imaging engine are the key differentiators in this camera as they help this camera with high iso setting images by keeping the noise levels down thereby making this a terrific camera for low light scenarios.What good is taking along a travel digital camera if it cannot produce dslr like quality images? The Olympus Pen system with the detachable lenses still weigh more than a point and shoot, but weigh far less and take up much less space in a camera bag than a full sized dSLR camera kit with lenses and accessories.Having the camera with you at all times will ensure that you get the rare photo or candid that usually happens only a few times a year. Carrying an Olympus Pen with a lens attached is so much easier on the shoulders and back than say a Canon Digital Rebel or a Nikon with the kit lens.Before you make that upgrade to a dSlR, check out the Olympus Pen and you will not be disappointed. You will find that it can do almost 90-95% of what an entry or medium advanced consumer dSLR can do function and image quality wise.You'll look even less dorky by carrying and shooting with such a cool looking and innovative camera.

Reviews.Title: Amzing pictures from a wonderful camera - E-PL1
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Choices choices choices! If you are reading this then you are probably experiencing the same dilemma that I went through.Let me start by stating that I know very little about photography. I am one of those normal guys snapping at things in the street, taking family photos and taking holiday pics. I do enjoy looking at nice pictures though I dont want all the hassle.I wanted to move up from my excellent compact P&S; (Fuji 200EXR) but was in a dilemma over what to buy. The pictures the Fuji produced had gotten me more interested in photography but did I want to commit to a buying a Carrera or an SLK? I wanted something that could produce better image quality and do those blurry backgrounds like you see in magazines.Some friends told me to buy a DSLR but I already had a film SLR bought 15 years ago that I hardly ever used. It was just too heavy and bulky for me to enjoy carrying around my neck for long periods of time. I must had gotten through 10 rolls of film in those 15 years. They also told me that the lens included in the kit wasnt that good so I had to factor in another $300-$400 for extra lenses.I also considered "Superzooms" like the Panasonic FZ35 - but then the picture quality might just the same as my Fuji (or perhaps worse) as the sensor is half the size of the Fuji F200. They were also not that small - certainly not trouser pocket size. And what was I going to zoom in on? Taking pictures of the neighbours cat might be fun for a while but how often would I really use that much zoom?Then I found out about these little micro 4/3 babies. I must admit that it was a hard choice between the Panasonic GF1 and this one. I liked the feel of the GF1 more and the screen was better. However, as a novice photographer I wanted the security of in-body stabilisation which the Panasonic didn't have.I also didnt want to bother with "post-processing" using Photoshop (something my DSLR friends seemed to enjoy) and everyone (and the reviewers) said that the Olympus produced the best JPEG output straight from the camera of the two. Even better were the art filters - the grainy film and the soft focus especially. There is even a "blurry background for dummies" control with just two clicks!The last clincher was the price... the Olympus was $200 cheaper. The Panasonic was the about same price as the Canon 550 DSLR.Weighing up the pros against the cons the EPL-1 was the best choice for a guy like me - a novice photographer on a budget.

Reviews.Title: Good for pros and intermediates
Reviews.Author: K. Adele
Reviews.Content: This camera can be used by pros, gifted amateurs and intermediates alike. It is fine for beginners who are serious about becoming good photographers. Beginners who are looking for a P&S; with interchangeable lenses will be unhappy, because you need to know something -- not alot -- about photo basics that go beyond pointing and shooting.One of its great attractions is that if all you want is a high-quality, low cost SLR, you can have it by buying the base model at a fantastic price with the kit lens (an unbelievable $260 for astonishing technology). Basically, this option provides you with an upscale P&S; at an unbelievable price.If you are serious about becoming a decent photographer, you don't work with LCD displays -- you want a viewfinder, which will cost an additional $250. So the camera now costs $510.The quality of pix with the 14-42 kit lens is okay, but not in the same league as what I get with my Nikon D7000 or my unbelievably sharp Fuji X100. If you want really clear shots that win awards in photo contests, then you must pay an additional $500 bucks for a Panasonic Lumix pancake lens -- 20mm, with an impressive f1.7 aperture. (Note: 20mm with 4/3 = 40mm with standard 35mm cameras) You have now reached the $1,000 range, and have a decent, light weight camera that might win you a prize or two in photo contests. Important note: If what you want is a walk around camera, get the fixed lens Fuji X100 for $1,200. The crispness of its photos would impress Ansel Adams.If you are going to shoot tigers and such at a distance, then you need to spend another $300 for a 40mm-150mm telephoto lens (equivalent to 80mm-300mm in the 35mm world). Your now $1,300 camera can get decent results with this lens. Personally, if I want good telephoto shots, I will lug my larger Nikon D7000 to get crystal clear shots of the lion taking down the zebra at 500 meters. Telephoto shots on the E-PL1 may win you a prize if you get a unique shot, but they won't give you the clarity you get with larger CMOS cameras.The big secret with the E-PL1, for those who want near professional level performance, is the 9mm-18mm wide angle lens ($500-$600). Wow! Great results: 90% of what I get with my Nikon D-7000 with a wide angle lens. In looking at reviews of this camera, I haven't see comments of this great capability. Check out newspaper photos and advertising photos: most are wide angle. That's what the pros use. The tiny Olympus with a 9mm-18mm lens can give you fantastic, crystal clear wide angle photos.Here's the configuration I suggest for the prospective E-PL1 buyer. Buy the standard camera (with kit lens) for $260. Pay an additional $250 for the viewfinder. Spend $500 for the Lumix high-performing, 20mm f1.7 lens. Finally, buy the wide angle 9mm-18mm lens for $500-$600. Total cost: $1,600 for an extremely light weight camera system that will get you great photos.But, if all you want is an SLR upgrade to your P&S;, spring for the measley $260 for the basic camera, which gives you a great camera that you may want to upgrade, as you develop your photo shooting skills.

Reviews.Title: Small Wonder
Reviews.Author: David L. Moore "David Moore"
Reviews.Content: Mainly, I was interested in this camera because of its small size and high definition (12.3MP).  In terms of the high definition, I wanted a camera capable, as is the PEN E-PL1, of saving photos in RAW format which allows for maximum leeway in using computer software to adjust brightness and color of the photos while maintaining sharp focus.  I am pleased that the 14-42mm zoom kit lens is capable of very sharp images with nice color.  The zoom equals 28mm-84mm in 35mm-equivalent terms and so provides an ample gamut of zoom for most photographic work.  The f/3.5 maximum aperture is not as open as some might wish, but it is capable of capturing bokeh; and, for those who want a lens with a lower f-stop, there are other lenses available for this camera at an added price.In terms of size, being a mirrorless digital camera, the PL1 is small enough to be relatively unobtrusive.  It comes with a strap that is quite adequate which attaches to each side of the camera so that it may be carried around the neck.  But it is compact enough that I decided to attach a wrist loop to one of the brackets for the strap; I found that I could easily carry it in one hand that way while the wrist loop provides security to keep it from being accidentally dropped.  With the 14-42mm zoom lens attached, it would be difficult to carry in a pocket; but with the shorter, 17mm lens (available separately) it could easily be slipped into a pocket or purse.  I purchased a small camera bag which fits the camera with the kit lens attached and leaves room to carry another lens or the battery-charging equipment which comes with the PL1.I have only a few complaints.  The battery takes a good long while to recharge, so I will either have to plan ahead and have a charged-up battery whenever I plan to take the camera along.  Otherwise I could shell out for a second battery (proprietary, of course) and always have a charged battery on hand.  I also found a problem in focusing the camera in low light.  I was doing a 3-second exposure with a tripod, and I found that the LCD monitor on the back of the camera provided no definition at that light level; even putting the camera on autofocus did not help.  I didn't try illuminating the scene with a flashlight; that might have worked.  What I did was take about 20 shots at progressively incremental focus; that did produce at least one well focused photograph.  There are external flashes available for purchase which provide illumination for focusing; they can be attached by hot shoe.  In bright sunlight it can be hard to see the LCD on the back of the camera.  But there are viewfinders available for purchase which attach to the camera's hot shoe.  Reviews on their functioning are mostly positive.  Since all of my complaints can be addressed by purchasing additional equipment, I have not hesitated to give the Pl1 the best rating, especially since the basic price of the PL1 seems to me very reasonable for this very capable camera.I have used this camera for about 2 weeks mostly in manual mode and am very pleased with the spot-on focusing and exposure it achieves.  On the occasions I have used the auto mode the photos have also turned out very well.  The boot-up of the program upon turning the camera on is very quick.  And the shutter button, while not instantaneous, is very rapid for a digital camera, at least in manual mode which is how I have mostly used it.  It has a built-in flash that can be flipped up which is adequate as a fill flash on short- to close-medium-range shots.  The software that controls the camera allows for a wide range of options.  Certain buttons can be programmed to various functions.  I found that programming a button to make the LCD show how the shot would appear in black & white can be very helpful.  The four-thirds format is new to me as I'm used to working in two-thirds format, but with 12.3MP there is plenty of room to crop to the shape and size the photographer wants, and the four-thirds format, just as it comes out of the camera, fits very well on an eight-and-a-half by eleven inch sheet of photo paper.  There are cameras that can capture higher resolution, but the biggest paper my photo printer handles is 13 by 19 inches, and I can print at this size without any noticeable grain.To sum up, I have found the Olympus PL1 to be a versatile camera, capable of seriously good quality photographs all in a compact package.  I am happy with my purchase, and I feel I have received a great deal of camera for the price.

Reviews.Title: Easy, trouble free, NOT for people wanting total manual control
Reviews.Author: opdoc "opdoc"
Reviews.Content: Pros:Fantastic picsEasy to UseLive View like Point and ShootiAuto works 99% of the timeSCN mode actually is usefulCarefree photographyAwesome pic quality for someone used to Point and Shoot qualitySo light in weight (as light as certain megazoom Point and Shoot cameras)Easy to lug around (compact size)RAW shootingCons:Manual control buttons absentLow light focus huntingMay need a pancake lens for quick focus in low lightScene modes have a delay after snap taken for processingHaving used the camera for more than a month now, it is a joy. Having upgraded from a Canon S3 this camera has amazing picture quality (supported by Dpreview). iAuto works most of the time except in low light where focus keeps hunting.Not the best camera if you need total manual control as most manual functions are menu driven without dedicated buttons.Other than that I love the new pics taken. Enjoy for those who have it. (I bought it for $260 or so that came with the 14-42 mm kit lens. Also ordered a Panasonic 45 -200mm lens for zoom options.I look forward to the Four-Thirds future!

Reviews.Title: The best camera $250 can buy -- DLSR-like image quality
Reviews.Author: AK
Reviews.Content: Overall, this is an amazing camera.  Image quality is fantastic, and you can pair it with some really top-notch Micro 4/3 lenses.  The Olympus 45mm f/1.8 and the Panasonic 20mm f/1.7 primes are both really fantastic.  The 14-42 kit lens itself is not bad at all, though it's not a very fast lens at f/3.5.  And the real kicker is the price -- at just over $250, this is cheaper than mid-to-high-end point & shoots, and a couple hundred bucks cheaper than even the entry level DLSRs.  It's a full-fledged interchangeable-lens camera that competes with DSLRs on image quality, and point-and-shoots on price!This camera does have its drawbacks.  For one, auto-focus speed is slow -- you'll notice this mostly if you're shooting moving subjects, not so much otherwise.  Also, full manual controls are there, but a bit hard to access -- the dials and on-screen menus needed to manually adjust settings are a bit clunky; the camera is really designed for the person who will spend 90% of their time in automatic mode.  If it had cost $500 instead of around $250, I would've deducted a star for these.  However, at its price point, it's by far the best camera you can buy.

Reviews.Title: my digital back
Reviews.Author: Wels Musgrave
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Olympus Pen e-PL1 camera chiefly for the availability of the adapter to my Minolta Lens. Using Minolta glass and aperture priority mode, I have essentially a digital back for my superior Minolta lens. With the built-in stabiliser, photographs taken with my 5oomm mirror lens (on this camera that translates to 1000mm in four/thirds format) are brilliantly clear. The added advantage of a wider range of f stops (50mm f1.4 - f16) makes a difference in low light photography. Coupled with a class 10 16Gig memory card and shooting in RAW, I have an awesome combination.

Reviews.Title: Favorite camera
Reviews.Author: Thommy
Reviews.Content: That's where the love for my camera comes in. I bought this because I was going to S. Korea to travel and on a tight budget and good reviews this camera sounded pretty good.Amazing travel camera.Small, light, great hot shoe for add-ons, a lot of lens' to choose from, can record in 720p HDI simply really like this camera. It's a great entry level camera for photographers and image quality is amazing.Very fun to have around.I would have given five stars but the kit Zuiko lens doesn't do the camera justice as the auto focus kind of sucks... bad.I say it sucks meaning it's just very slow. Some lens' auto focus way faster.Regardless I love the camera and am extremely satisfied with it.

Reviews.Title: Very pleased - a great camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Brian C. Driver
Reviews.Content: I used to be an avid film photographer in high school and college, but dropped it years ago.  Since then, I have had a series of adequate-to-downright disappointing point/shoots - the most recent is a Panasonic Lumix DMC-TZ4.  So I decided to treat myself to a new camera, and after much research, decided on the E-PL1 based on a combination of budget, capability, and quality.  After a few days of use, I'm very pleased with almost all aspects of this camera.PROS:-RAW mode - this is my first camera with this mode, so I can't really compare, but based on many of the reviews, the RAW images out of this camera have low-light/high-ISO noise levels that rival SLRs with larger sensors.  I must say being able to shoot in RAW mode and edit in the included "ib" software* surpasses all my expectations.  Being able to forget about white balance, exposure compensation, etc. and correct later takes a lot of the guesswork out of shooting - I've taken several shots in mixed lighting conditions and made them pop simply by applying accurate compensation, where doing so to a JPG would provide suboptimal results.  I've done some full-pixel crops that don't look half bad, and I chalk it all up to being able to shoot in RAW mode.-Noise levels are very low.  I've taken many low-light shots at ISO 800 or 1600 that look very decent - what noise there is looks more like film grain when viewed at reduced size or printed out, rather than the artifacting I've gotten out of my previous shooters.  The Panny I'm coming from for instance would introduce so much color noise in low-light shots anywhere above ISO 400 so as to make any shots unusable for anything but Facebook posts.-The video is incredible.  I thought he HD video out of my smartphone looked good, but this looks amazing.  Even though it's *only* 720p, on my 1080p 46" flat-screen, it looks outstanding.  I would even say that with a good (read: better than the kit) lens, this could be a credible (and super-cheap) starter camera for a film student or documentary maker (as long as you don't need to shoot a scene longer ~7 minutes due to the 2GB limitation).  The auto-focus hunts a bit, but a light touch on the shutter button and judicious framing will minimize this, and you can always focus in manual mode if necessary (though you can't switch focus mode - or anything - while filming).  I have a couple relatively minor complaints about video recording, addressed in the CONS section below, but both of which one can easily work around.-Size - this is a perfect size, heft, and shape, for me at least.  I can even shoot for a while one-handed without much fatigue - there's a raised "safety bump" to prevent you from inadvertently hitting the Movie Mode button, and with my thumb braced just beneath this, I can get a pretty good balance for a few shots, something that was not very easy with my old Canon AE-1 and Pentax K1000.  Even though it's got a plastic body, it's very well put together.-The built in flash is a convenience I'd never had in an SLR before.  And while, like any built in flash, it's only useful to a few feet away, the color balance is quite good, and it doesn't lead to blown highlights.CONS-The biggest con is the kit lens, although for such a great price I shouldn't complain, since it would be impossible to find a quality lens for the delta between the kit and body only prices.  The optics seem decent enough, although soft around the corners when zoomed in, but the barrel has a bit of play both in wide-angle and telephoto positions.  This means if you shoot at certain speeds between around 1/80 to 1/200, the shutter movement can rattle the lens, causing a slight blur, although if you shoot in the middle of the zoom range, this is less likely to happen, since the lens is retracted and has less play.  .  To be fair, this will only be noticable very close up, so for small prints and web sharing, it shouldn't be noticeable - if you want crystal-clear full-size prints, get better glass.  Next big investment of mine will be some quality optics.-As mentioned above, there are a couple minor drawbacks with video recording.  1) The in-body microphone will pick up the zoom and auto-focus noises from the lens.  This can be qutie distracting, and if you plan on doing a lot of recording, the Olympus SEMA-1 external mic adapter is highly recommended, as it should isolate the mic from the lens motor and solve this problem - this will be my next purchase**.  2) The video sizes in the Motion-jpeg/AVI format are HUUGE.  A 3 minute-long video took almost 750 MB - at this rate, I will need a lot of SD cards.  The good news is that the video compresses down quite nicely to more familiar and compatible formats without much loss in quality - I used Handbrake to compress this video from 750 down to 310 MB in size, with a negligible-to-nil difference in quality (h.264 format, High Profile with Constant Quality set to RF 15 and audio set to pass-through).  I would highly recommend becoming familiar with Handbrake or similar transcoding tools if you plan on using this for video recording.-*While I love being able to edit RAW images, the provided software is a bit slow and cumbersome to use.  This may simply be a limitation of editing RAW images since they are so large, but the interface could use some polish.-**The mic accessory attaches to the hot shoe, and blocks the connection, so you won't be able to use any other accessories like the optional viewfinder or a flash.  Not a big issue for me, but if you plan to do a lot of mixed-mode shooting, go for a model with an external mic connector onboard.-The only other complaint I have is that some of the default settings on this camera are buried in the setup menus, and perhaps should have been covered upfront in the user guide.  For instance, in Manual Focus mode, there is the option to zoom in to a magnified view as soon as you rotate the focus ring.  This is quite handy, and *should* be the default setting, but it took a lot of hunting through the manual and a couple layers of menus to turn this on.

Reviews.Title: Best interchangeable lens camera for the price
Reviews.Author: SeaDav
Reviews.Content: If you are willing to invest some time understanding how to work with this camera, it can provide excellent results. There is a lot of customization available to tweak the picture quality and the user interface.I like:- Excellent image quality, probably due to the weak low pass filter. Images are crisp and details are kept even at 100% magnification. You can completely disable noise reduction (this is rare with other camera brands). You can also configure sharpening, color, etc  ...- Jpegs are greats.- Image stabilization is independent of the lens: it can be used with legacy manual film lenses. However it is not perfect (see below).- Can use really cheap but excellent manual focus film lenses (see keh) with an inexpensive adapter. I tried a 50mm (100mm with the m4/3 sensor) F1.7 Minolta Rokkor lens and it is giving fantastic results! Maybe because the lens was created for a bigger sensor (the m4/3 sensor is half the size of a film) there are very few distortions. This is way better that the kit lens.- The body shape is great and provides a good hold.I dislike:- No HDR capability :-(. Bracketed shots are limited 3 shots at 1 EV (e.g. 3 EV max range). Exposure can be changed manually but it is too slow to capture even slowly moving scenes in HDR. Cannot understand this limitation ??!- Image stabilization leaves a blur at all shooting speeds with the default settings, even at faster speeds. After experimenting and searching the web, using the anti-shock =1/8s  (buried in the menus) seems to solve the issue. When shooting with enough light, it is better to disable Stabilization.- Screen is not sunlight readable and it attracts fingerprints. This is solved with a screen hood.- The camera zooms up to 14x to help with manual focus in full screen. This works but makes composition tricky. When taking portrait shots, zoom in at a face feature (e.g. eyes, nose, ...) and quickly go back to full scene view to confirm composition, then go back to refocus and take the shot (you can re-assign a button to switch back and forth). I much prefer the picture in picture system used in Canon compacts which let you do both at the same time.- Autofocus is slow, and degrades in low light, but it is not worse than other brands of mirrorless cameras.No camera is perfect, but if you are looking for an inexpensive camera with pro level results, this is the best model available in my opinion. The image quality is exceptional for the price, but only if you know how to use the camera (not just from a photography angle, but from a feature tweaking point of view). It is a pleasure to use with legacy lenses and produces excellent pictures.

Reviews.Title: Incredible
Reviews.Author: Indyjoel
Reviews.Content: This is the perfect DSLR.  It is small, easy to use and it doesn't break the bank.  I have had mine for a year and I have used it a ton.  My pictures have come out wonderfully.  I also purchased the 44mm-135mm zuiko lens and my photos have turned out better than the stock one.  I have made several HD videos with it for work and it played well with Aperture and iMovie.  The best part is that I don't need a back pack to haul it around.  I throw it in my small case i have for it or my fiancee's purse and we are on our way.  While the professional photographer may scoff at it, this camera packs a punch for the hobbits!

Reviews.Title: Adore it now that I have figured out the settings.
Reviews.Author: H. Rolfe
Reviews.Content: It took a little time to get used to having to change a setting to go from taking pictures of my little dogs to taking macros of flowers or plants (the old camera before this one did that without changing anything). The auto settings work well for most things, but for macro I switch to the priority aperture setting and change the setting up some. On the auto setting the focal length is too tight for most flowers to come out sharp allover the flower you are focusing on. If the dogs are running around and I want to be sure of a blur free picture I switch to the SCN setting for children and it works great.Low light doesn't faze this camera on the auto setting. I have taken pics with the flash that look like daytime at light levels where I wasn't even sure what the camera had focused on. Also there's a flash setting that's simple to switch to that will eliminate most red eye problems.I can fit it into the pocket of my jacket for vacations with either the pancake lens or the kit 14-42mm lens on and get awesome pictures with little fuss. My only gripe is that while the included lens will show you a very zoomed in sharp image on-screen it won't take that zoomed in part as the picture. If it could I'd never change cameras again.Overall if you want great pictures and want a light-weight camera that is compact for what it can do this is for you. If you want something to fit in your pants pocket this is not a point and shoot.

Reviews.Title: Happy Compromise
Reviews.Author: John Metcalf
Reviews.Content: I was looking to move up from my Canon point & shoot, but wasn't really looking to get fully into the DSLR thing. I had my era of film SLR bodies and multiple lenses and just don't want to drag all that stuff around anymore (I'm not a pro-photographer.)I liked what the E-PL1 offered--a compact body, the opportunity to add lenses if I wish, good low-light shooting, and sharp, quality images. I've since purchased an adaptor ring to let me use my old manual Nikon lenses and the image quality is perfect. Probably won't use them much, but for the small investment, I get to use my old collection that would otherwise be collecting dust. The one downside to the camera setup here is that the limitations of the lens. I'm happy with the quality, but I will probably buy a telephoto or more powerful zoom in the future. Don't expect the 14-42mm to get you good nature photography (birds appear VERY far away.)A tip for those shopping for cameras: visit Flickr and browse images by the camera you're looking at. It will give you an idea of the type and quality of photography the camera is capable of. I was prepared to buy a more expensive micro 4/3 camera, but found that the Olympus images were just as good, if not better, than those of similar compact interchangeable lens cameras.

Reviews.Title: I love it!
Reviews.Author: C. McDougle
Reviews.Content: I had my doubts about this camera after reading a ton of online camera reviews. I decided that reviews always have to be taken with a grain of salt, so I ordered it.I love this camera, it's fun to use. The autofocus is fine.. It's not a DSLR and so it doesn't perform as well as a high end camera would. However,  after updating to firmware 1.1 the autofocus works pretty well. I am a little disappointed that it doesn't have an AF Lamp. That would have improved low light performance greatly.. But i guess you can't have everything.I think like a previous reviewer said, you need to be honest about how you will use the camera and what your expectations are. For me, this camera is a gem, but i'm not a pro looking for exceptional results. I just want to snap a few great pictures and have some fun.Most of my images are of animals - i.e. Dogs and cats. The camera is just fine for this. I know some reviews say otherwise. However, as any pet owner or parent knows animals and kids are unpredictable. There is no guarantee of a perfect shot with even the highest end camera. When photographing active and rambunctious subjects, it's partly about knowing your subject and partly luck.  For it's class. this camera does pretty darn well.I have also read that people thought the camera felt flimsy and cheap because it was mostly plastic. That's simply not true. It feels no less plastic than any DSLR. Honestly, it's heavier than I imagined and built like a brick - very sturdy. Unless you are just really rough on your gear, I can't imagine this camera falling apart on you.. even with everyday use.Some say the flash isn't that powerful, but this camera seems to do a good job in lowlight situations. It would do even better in low light with the 20mm panasonic lens or with a faster manual focus lens. I , myself, am using a 50mm 1.8 lens from an old film camera. As far as the flash, it's still pretty bright. You are after all trying to take a picture, not make your subject  blind.The art filters & multi exposure options are a lot of fun. I can't wait to get some more lenses ( such as a lensbaby)  and go out into the world with them. My favorite is the grainy B&W; with the Diorama mode being second. If you have doubts about the art modes, you can always shoot in Jpg + raw and get the best of both worlds.I am only giving this 4 stars because i DO wish it came with an EVF. I think it's silly that i have to pay almost $200 more for this very basic feature.  I wish it had stereo sound like it's big sister the e-p2 as well.Also as a Mac user, I am a little disappointed the included software isn't compatible. It took me a few minutes ( due to bad links on the Oly website) to find the OM2 software ( I will only use for panoramas, personally).

Reviews.Title: Premium Image Quality in a Compact Size
Reviews.Author: pveman
Reviews.Content: I've been shooting with a Canon 20D SLR for 5 years and during that time I've been looking for a camera that I could fit in my pocket that could get essentially the same image quality.  I went through several P&S; models and was ultimately disappointed in all of them.  I was very excited when I saw new micro 4/3 models so I decided to buy the E-PL1.  I have to say I am quite satisfied.In my opinion, the most important thing about a camera is image quality.  From that perspective, the E-PL1 is a truly outstanding camera.  The jpeg images coming out of the camera are significantly superior to what I get out of the 20D SLR. It is important to note, however, that the RAW files from the 20D can be processed to look slightly better than the E-PL1 jpegs.  But most people I know would rather have 95% of the image quality straight out of the camera than needing to fiddle with post processing.  The E-PL1 images are much cleaner than my Fuji F100FD.The pop-up flash is an nice added bonus.  You can actually manually aim the flash at the ceiling to create a softer "bounce flash" which provides much more even lighting than "direct flash."  It makes a big difference.Video quality is another bonus in this camera.  It's a little more challenging to use than P&S; user will be used to.  Because of the larger sensor in this camera, it is capable of a much narrower depth of field.  While this leads to much more "natural" photos and videos, it also means that you need to be much more careful about keeping your subject in focus.  This can be a challenge for moving subjects in video - especially since the focusing on the E-PL1 is a little sluggish.  However, if you take a second to pre-focus the camera by pressing the shutter button down half way, you can get your subject nicely in focus.  Although the mechanical image stabilization does not work during video shooting, the camera does use an electronic substitution.  It's not as good, but as a former professional videographer I can testify that it is definitely better than nothing.  I have no problem holding the camera steady for must video shots.Speaking of the mechanical image stabilization, this feature leads to one of the greatest uses for this camera - low light shooting without a flash.  Because the image stabilization is in the body, you can attach a prime lens with a wide aperture and shoot indoors in low light with moderate shutter speeds.  Add in that the photos look so good up to 1600 ISO and you can get some remarkably clear hand-held pictures in low light.  I absolutely love the natural light pictures I have been able to take.  Keep in mind, however, that the auto-focus struggles in really low light.  But it has generally worked for me and the manual focusing is pretty easy to use.Overall, the camera is a terrific value for the price.  I highly recommend it for anyone who puts a priority on image quality in a compact camera - especially if you do not like to spend a lot of time post-processing the image.

Reviews.Title: Why No Cable Release?
Reviews.Author: M. Mullins "Book to Book"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the E-PL1 to replace my canon G10 as my every day walk around camera.  The G10, while a wonderful camera, can't be used much beyond ISO 400 because of the noise levels produced by its small sensor.  The E-PL1 exhibits very little noise even at ISO 1600.  The focusing, while slower than a traditional dSLR, is fairly quick and is noticeably quicker than my G10. There are a couple of omissions from the E-PL1 that might make this camera undesirable for a select group of photographers.  First, there is no cable release available for the E-PL1 and, according to the Olympus representative I spoke to, there are no plans to introduce a cable release for this model.  Second, there isn't a focus assist lamp built into the E-PL1 which makes auto focusing in extremely low light impossible.  Finally, if you plan to use the E-PL1 outdoors in direct sunlight get the VF-2 electronic viewfinder; the LCD screen is difficult to see in direct sunlight.  Overall, I'm extremely happy with my E-PL1.  It produces great images in line with my Nikon D90 while being closer in size to my Canon G10.5/10/10 Update:The motor in the 14-42 lens is not powerful enough to use a Cokin P-Series filter system.  I thought I would be able to take advantage of the Cokin filters I already own, however with the Cokin filter holder attached the focus keeps hunting and eventually refuses to work at all; I can still use the Cokin system with the E-PL1 in manual focus mode.5/17/10 Update:The battery life is not great.  I only got about 185 shots and 5 minutes of video on a fully charged battery on my last outing.

Reviews.Title: Gus'  review of the E-PL1
Reviews.Author: Gus K. Folk "Gus Folk"
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera... after paying $600.00 for the camera ... we will have to wait until the converter to my E-500 lens comes down in price as I have quite a few lens for the E-500...We didn't want to have to take the E-500 to Hawaii with us since it is much larger and heavier than the E-PL1...I think around $100.00 is enough to have to pay for the Olympus MMF-1 Four Thirds to Micro Four Thirds Adapter.  The cheapest that I have found it for when searching the Internet is $160.00... Maybe it will get down to a decent price before we go on our next big trip after our Hawaii trip...The instant ways that you can change the settings is absolutely great... You will have to go into the menu and fix the video start red button to work to instantly start the video as advertised... I thought the red button on the camera was broken for several weeks after receiving the camera but searched out the menu and found the setting for the Red Button...all... this truly is a great camera!

Reviews.Title: Comparisons surprising
Reviews.Author: Karen P. Fletcher "seminolewind"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera, a canon t2i, and a panasonic fz200 .  I used them all with and without a tripod, mostly on animals, bugs, and nature.  Out of the 3, I kept the Olympus.The panasonic fz200 was awesome.  Fun to use and took great pics.  The canon I was a bit disappointed in, mainly the autofocus time, and inconsistent auto color.  Maybe these things are beyond how much I have to fiddle with a camera.I took pictures with all of them, freehand and with tripod, and at home on the computer, I could not tell the difference in quality.  The Olympus has 12.3 megapixels, and the canon has 18, and I expected to be able to blow up and crop the canon pictures much more, but could not.  The pictures fell apart at the same enlargement as the other 2.  The panasonic was outstanding even without a tripod.  But those 2 were not any better then the Olympus Pen epl-1.  The other reason I chose it over the Panasonic is that I have to turn the lens itself for closer/farther, where the panasonic had a toggle.  Hand on lens is far more quick and controlable when it comes to getting the distance you want.  I did not find that the autofocus took too long, but longer than my pocket camera.  With the canon, I more often missed the picture waiting for the autofocus to focus.I am not a professional.  But I enjoy seeing how good I can get a clear quality picture without being a professional.  And I am the blow-up and crop queen, it's extremely important to me.  The Olympus is up there equal to the best with less fuss.  The canon took too long to autofocus, and the Panasonic FZ200 was a hard one to give up, but turning the lens for distance on the Olympus was much more enjoyable than the toggle on the panasonic.Update 1/24/13Okay, I got curious.  I bought a Sony slt a57.  It was rated better than the pl1.  I went out and shot 120 pictures.  It did not beat the Pen epl1.  The clearest shots got blurry before they broke up with the Sony, as enlarged.  With the Pen the pictures break up first and do not get blurry.  The Sony seemed to have less than a focus area than the Pen.  Meaning that more of the outer edges of the item were blurry, whereas, the Pen gives a larger area of clarity without impeding on the bokeh or background blur.  The Sony is easier to use the menus, but the trade-off is the bulk. The Sony is easily twice the size and weight. The clear pictures with the Sony, I find , are a hair softer than the PEN. I can't see lugging that camera around my neck for the day.  All my comparisons were done freehand with some enlargement and cropping of the picture.Meaning that they were only compared by making the pictured item closer up in the laptop picture edit.  And all were taken with the Auto program. All the cameras I tested had an upgraded lens.  If I had to do it all over again, I would have not wasted my time comparing this awesome Pen e-pl1 to popular midrange DSLR cameras.  This Olympus PEN is majorly overlooked as a popular camera, which is great because you save a lot of money buying it.  It's a gem.

Reviews.Title: Step up from point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Jesse V. Johnson
Reviews.Content: I fit the market that this product is targeted at; owner of higher end point and shoots (Canon G series), and until now using mostly the automatic or scene modes. I was attracted by the better image quality, high definition video, and interchangeable lenses.POSITIVES:The camera has exceeded my expectations. I've found that using different lenses has changed the way I think about photography, and opened the door to a whole new world. This camera is easy adapted to use hundreds of old lenses with manual focus. Initially, I was intimidated by this, but soon found that manual focusing is easy with the help of the digital zoom mode, accessible with a single button press. One can purchase an adapter for about $40, and really nice lenses begin around at $50 used at your local camera shop, or on e-bay.
