For someone stepping up from point and shoot, this is very exciting.Image quality is excellent, and the large sensor allows much, much better low light photography; basically allowing you to do things you wouldn't think of with a point and shoot, and leave the color draining flash off. You also get a smaller depth of field, and photos will have that professional looking blurred background. A personal preference, but I like the way Olympus cameras handle color, and think the photos look really good in that regard. I do not shoot RAW, but like that the camera allows me to do that if I want.The camera is responsive. I know that this is probably only true for someone that has only used point and shoots in the past, and this camera is considered sluggish compared to DSLR cameras in terms of auto focus. But, it's really not a problem for me, and I consider some of the discussion about that issue to be misleading. It is plenty fast, and even faster if you get a Panasonic lens, like the excellent 20mm f1.7. Qualitatively, to me, it seems about twice as fast with Panasonic lenses.NEGATIVES:I wish it were a little smaller. While, smaller than any DSLR, it is still big compared to many P and S cameras. Mine quit working after about 20 days, but Amazon's customer service is great, and I think I'm back on track. Not sure what happened, may a little rain got to where it shouldn't? I agree with others, this camera would be much better if it had a dial, like the EP-1 and EP-2. Using the four way button controller is a little awkward as you start customizing settings. These are the things that prevent me from giving it 5/5 stars. Overall, a great camera.

Reviews.Title: A Nice Camera But A Bit of A Mixed Bag
Reviews.Author: shuTTL3bus "shuTTL3bus @gmail .com"
Reviews.Content: What do you get when you take Olympus PEN and mix it with a stripper (Of course I mean someone who strips features from a camera). You get the E-PL1 camera which is a little bit of a mixed bag. On the one hand you have one of the best versions of the m4/3 sensor to date. From what I have read it is better than both the E-P1 and E-P2 sensors. It is hard to tell the difference at normal screen and printing resolutions and I take a picture at its whole and don't pixel peep so I cannot verify that. What I can say is this camera is capable of producing world class images. Additionally, this camera has the Olympus JPEG engine which is regarded in the business as one of the best. This camera is also relatively small and light and includes a fill flash. Additionally, it has image stabilization (IS) built into the camera. It is not pocketable and the size of this camera has more to do with the lens that it is wearing then the actual camera itself.On the other hand, you have a camera that is slow to focus. It appears to me that it zooms to infinity (and beyond) and then catches the focus on its way back in. If you are taking pictures of forever-in-motion kids you can be sure you will miss quite a few decisive moments. Additionally, this camera lacks the most important camera control there is. This is the control wheel used to change exposure, aperture, and shutter settings in a quick efficient manner. Instead this camera uses buttons which is an unwieldy way of making these changes. Most higher end Point and Shoot (P+S) cameras have some version of this control wheel. I think anyone transitioning to this camera from a DSLR or high end P+S will be frustrated by this. I've seen this billed as a good thing as there are less controls to get confused over. That may be so but all m4/3 cameras can be used as point and shoot by just keeping in the intelligent Auto(iA) mode. This simplifies the menu options and takes great pictures a majority of the time.I think for anyone who wants to step up from a P+S to take better Image Quality pictures but plans to stay in the iA mode 90% of the time, then this camera will serve you well and will take some amazing images. Just remember P+S type focusing speed.Anyone, who has a E-P1or E-P2 who want a sensors with a weaker Anti-Aliasing filter (i.e. less detail lost to the AA filter) and a fill flash will enjoy this camera for the IQ but will probably be frustrated with the loss of the control wheelAnyone either stepping up from a high end P+S such as the LX3, S90, or G11 will be impressed with the images, but not blown away by the difference, unimpressed with the P+S focus performance, and frustrated in the P, A, S or M shooting modes. Additionally, you will be unimpressed with the bigger size of the camera but will enjoy the flexibility if your budget includes other lenses.Anyone, getting this as a second carry around camera to a DSLR, will be happy with the smaller size and weight but unhappy with the slower performance. And frustrated by the clumsy controls but happy with the video capabilities.If you don't need or want the video, don't mind IS in the lens instead of the camera, and can put up with a slight decrease in you IQ, ISO, and JPEG performance, then the Panasonic Lumix DMC-G1 12.1MP Digital Camera with Lumix G Vario 14-45 mm f/3.5-5.6 ASPH Mega OIS Lens (Red) offers many upgrades at the same price (Integrated 1.4mp EVF, Swivel Screen, 460k screen, Grip for bigger lenses, faster focus performance, etc)For the same price, the newly announced G10 matches the E-PL1 with video, and new processing engine (cross your fingers for a JPEG improvement). Additionally, it has a 2kp EVF (I'm not sure how useful that will be), a grip, a control wheel, a 1/4000 shutter speed and faster focus performance. It does not have in-camera IS.For those planning on getting the EVF at some point or with an ~$200 greater budget, check out the newly announced G2. Take the G1, add 720P 60/50fps video, an improved processing engine, a new dial to change focusing modes, touch screen controls that look to work as slick as an iPhone, and touch screen focus, and you have a really really nice full featured camera.Finally, if you don't need interchangeable lenses or don't plan on buying any more lenses and you don't mind a degradation of IQ, then the Canon S90, Canon G11, and Panasonic LX3(Leica D-Lux 4) are easier to carry around everywhere (especially the S90) and are cheaper(the gap will close when the price of this camera falls).Here is a quick list of pros and cons of the E-PL1ProsThe best Olympus implementation of the m4/3 sensorOne of the best JPEG engines in the businessRelatively small and lightBuilt in flashIn camera Image Stabilization(IS)Price (The cheapest m4/3 yet)Optional EVF (A very nice 1.4mp unit but very pricy at $279)Its availableNice build qualityConsSlow Autofocus (Panasonic has this figured out. Olympus, not so much)Missing Control Wheel slows down aperture, shutter, and exposure changesOnly 230k screen?!1/2000 shutter speed?! A lot of P+S go to 1/4000Locking lens is annoying to deploy and stowOverallA competent and nice camera that will take stunning images. Slow autofocus and clunky controls will make this camera frustrating to many people.

Reviews.Title: pro quality images for around $100 (now) You can't beat that
Reviews.Author: Iman Roder
Reviews.Content: Just got this camera (which is now 4 years old) and I am extremely happy with what I got for the price. I essentially got a $400 camera for $100!  The speed, resolution, lcd screen and af capability of the camera may not be as good as the latest breed of cameras but it definitely delivers high quality photos, which I think is what counts. It even works great with the larger four-thirds lens on e-series slr cameras (given an adapter). I recommend the Neewer plastic AF Focus adapter. It's much cheaper than the Olympus brand adapter and works just as well. Overall if your on a budget, now is a great time to go for a used digital camera. Just 5 years ago going used was not a good idea because then, older digital cameras were still mediocre at best. But if you go 4 or 5 years back you're sure to find a great quality digital camera with 12 or so mega pixels at a great price. If you're not a professional photographer aiming to blow up your images to billboard size you definitely do not need a digital camera with more that 12 megapixels. Even that is overkill!

Reviews.Title: Great camera for beginners
Reviews.Author: Victoria
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera a year ago and I LOVE it! I have been able to capture some incredibly moments. The clarity is spectacular and the camera is lightweight which makes it perfect for on the go photography. This has truly been a fantastic beginner camera. It takes great macro, landscape, portraits, anything! Learn to use this camera and it can be your best friend!The cons that I've found:1. It doesn't focus as fast as I'd like and sometimes it refuses to focus on what you want. That's where manual comes in, but in nature photography getting the manual just right without a viewfinder took too long and I usually lost the subject.2. No viewfinder! This was frustrating with my daylight shots. Sometimes I'd think I got it just right only to come home and realize the glare on the screen fooled me again!All in all I've been very pleased with this camera and the quality of pictures it takes. It even gets incredible shots of the moon! If you're on a budget or you're just getting started in photography, this is your camera!

Reviews.Title: Incredible camera for this price
Reviews.Author: David
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent camera, with the right balance of point and shoot features and setting choices that a professional might need.  In my opinion, glass optics, which this camera has, are a must and many cameras today resort to acrylics.  You can use this camera entirely in manual mode, actually setting the f-stop and focus by adjusting the lens.  This is a plus for old 35mm users like myself who still want to set the camera the way we always did without fumbling through menus.  It self stabalizes, auto focuses, etc., all the things you want for picking a basic setting, i.e., landscapes, portraits, closeups, and just shoot away. The price came down to approximately half what this camera originally retailed for, so if you can still find one, Olympus lives up to it's brand in this one.

Reviews.Title: Great hobbyist camera
Reviews.Author: SpeedisaVirus
Reviews.Content: Camera does a pretty solid job. Especially at the current price point. Low light performance isn't fantastic but tweaking the settings can still get great shots if you are patient. The kit lens isn't that bad though I do like my pancake lens more for most on the go shooting.There are only 2 things I would love to have had:1. Visual viewfinder. You can buy one though so its not a tragic loss though it will prevent mounting an auxiliary flash at the same time.2. I would have probably liked to have the settings dial like on the E-PL2. I needed the camera short notice for a sudden vacation to Cobá for the "end of the world" and since I am a prime member I went with the prime eligible camera since they didn't seem that different beyond features such as this and the larger screen in general for simple basic shooting.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product; shipping excellent
Reviews.Author: Richard D. Harris "jazzboy"
Reviews.Content: This is the perfect camera for the person, like me, who likes the old range-finder/retro camera!  It is incredibly powerful and has all the features of the higher end cameras. Yet it also has a "user friendly" feature that you can make quick adjustments without going through the complete menu system.  Truly remarkable camera. As you know this is an older version of the Pen but that brings the cost down.  ALSO, the selling point for me was the ability to use my old OM lenses from film days!  With an adapter from Fotodiox you can get an adapter that will fit the major manufacturers of older lenses. This is a great bargain, and a powerful tool to record your memories.

Reviews.Title: Very Pleased
Reviews.Author: Steve Burger
Reviews.Content: I was excited to see and interchangeable lens camera under $300 new.  After researching the micro four thirds system I was eager to try.  This camera does lack some of the features of the top of the line cameras but with good lenses this camera competes with the old 35mm SLR cameras I used to have.  I'm only a hobbyist and no expert, but I don't see how anyone could be unhappy with this camera unless they were a pro and even then I would imagine this would be nice as a light weight travel rig.  Additionally, I have already used its ability to adapt old film-era lenses to great results.  I have purchased both a very nice portrait lens and a telephoto lens and due to low price of these legacy lenses I have an awesome rig for minimal investment.I would and have recommended this camera to anyone.

Reviews.Title: LARGE SENSOR - Great Video
Reviews.Author: William C. Chenoweth "wchenoweth"
Reviews.Content: Amazing almost realistic Video. I am a novice by far, my last digital camera was a consumer large size Kodak which is totally useless unless you are shooting in bright light. It was too hard for me to justify an SLR, but I wanted a camera that I could bring with me, have a smart mode and take photos fast while having good low level light performance, video capabilities and quality good enough to get 8x10s in almost any light level.This baby is just amazing, I would guess its quality is so good mainly from the sensor size being so big, you could fit 16 of my older kodak point and shoot sensors on this one 4/3rds sensor.I just shot this whole video with the camera [...] with regular auto settings. My son compressed it some in after effects so I didn't do a great job of showing its clarity, but you can hear some of the focusing and see the overall low light performance. It was dark and stormy as we waited for hurricane Sandy in Virginia Beach VA.I love this camera!

Reviews.Title: Very pleasantly suprised!
Reviews.Author: Hallolog
Reviews.Content: I'm not going to pretend to be a pro-photographer. I don't have the cash or technical skills to drop >$2k on a FX sensor DSLR. However, I do still take a good amount of pictures with point and shoots, and I found myself falling in love with this camera. The size and price were the main two reasons I chose this camera, small enough to tote around everywhere but yet large enough to take zoom shots with decent clarity. The intelligent auto is fantastic, and I find myself seldom straying from it. The only situations where I would stray would be taking photographs of the stars where I want a longer exposure, and taking pictures in a half-lit environment where it seems to overcompensate for the lighting. My title says 5 stars but really I would give it 4.5. The reason I give this a 4.5 star review as opposed to a 5 would be the autofocus. The pictures turn out great, however, often times you click to take a shot and it focuses, unfocuses, and forgets you ever pressed the button in the first place. This can be quite bothersome- especially during one instance where a biplane just happened to be flying overhead when I had this camera around my neck and I missed the shot entirely because it was too slow to focus.  Don't let that stop you from purchasing this camera! The price point that this camera is at hardly gives me room to rate it 4.5 stars, and it has been fantastic teaching me more about photography.

Reviews.Title: GREAT camera!
Reviews.Author: Evelyn A. Cummings
Reviews.Content: I own a Canon T3i and some Canon L lenses but I had read about the micro 4/3 systems and was interested in something smaller and easier to lug around for general purposes.  I found this camera as a return on Amazon Warehouse Deals and decided the price was right!  I also got the Panasonic 45 - 200 lens at the same time.When the camera initially arrived the kit lens was inoperable so I took a refund from Warehouse deals and ordered the Panasonic 14 - 42mm lens instead.In the beginning, I was not a happy shooter because every single time I held the camera and took some photos I was inadvertently turning on the movie mode since the button is right where my somewhat large thumb is placed.  I read the manual and couldn't find a way to kill the movie button so I was about ready to kill it with some glue.  Fortunately, prior to doing that I was looking for something else in the manual and discovered I COULD assign the Movie function to the mode dial and use the shutter instead so that was PERFECT!  I don't do video so it was really annoying me.The manual is not well written AT ALL, IMO.  It is quite difficult to find what you are looking for, and, often, even after you find it, it's difficult to understand.BUT...I LOVE this camera!!!  It IS light and small but it feels really solid and well made.  It is surprisingly balanced with the long lens attached.  And, everyone comments about how "cool" it looks!As for photos, I am really happy.  Sadly, I do not compose my shots, I crop, and I was worried about the low pixel count.  Apparently 4/3 DOES work and I don't miss them at all.  Photos are crisp and clear and the colors are outstanding... I always end up playing with levels and saturation and white balance when working up shots from the Canon but the ones from this camera were exactly what I wanted right out of the camera.I do miss the light gathering capacity of the Canon and those L lenses, but, hey, I knew that wasn't going to be the same when I ordered this camera AND I still have the Canon for those shots.I also love the extra length from a 4/3 system... my 200mm is now 400mm, and a great 400mm at that!While I KNOW this isn't the same camera as my Canon, it IS a great camera and is exactly what I was hoping it would be!!!  In fact, it is BETTER than I expected it would be and I can't wait for my first kayaking trip or run on the beach with the dogs!!  My back and neck feels better already!

Reviews.Title: Great Image Quality
Reviews.Author: Mr Fix-it
Reviews.Content: This camera was bought used and arrived promptly on the very 1st day of the estimate delivery-date-range. Camera with the kit lens are both in excellent conditions. Thought it is comparable in cost, size and weight as my LUMIX super-zoom camera, the picture quality seems better and has more details. It takes decent pictures even in low light after fine-tuning the settings. The adjustment on various settings is very simple with the pointer/button. This camera truly deserves a thorough reading of the instruction manual by the user to find what it is capable of. Its relatively compact size and weight will greatly help many of us serious but non-professional photographers to capture happy memories in great and professional-like pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great first camera
Reviews.Author: Michael P. Peterson "qwertyomen"
Reviews.Content: From a first time camera buyer, this is a great start. I don't really know a lot about photography (never taken any kind of class) and I'm already manually adjusting shutter and aperture settings. I was shocked at the size of the lense fully extended! and it feels heavier than it looks. Great camera.

Reviews.Title: For the price, you honestly cannot beat it.
Reviews.Author: AaronD
Reviews.Content: I've been in the market for a new camera for some time now. Constantly searching, and hunting for a camera that would soot my needs. There were three things i was looking for in my new camera. PICTURE QUALITY; as long as you know how to tweak the settings a bit, you will get out standing results. I am very happy with the sharpness, and detail. PRICE; Okay, so im not alone. some people are on a budget. Some people don't have $800 plus dollars to throw around. That's were this little guy comes in. For $289? how can you go wrong?! VERSATILITY; I needed a camera i can mess with to suit my needs. Interchangeable lens, better than good image sensor, and something i can lug around for hours at a time. this is were the little guy shines the most. because of the micro 4/3 technology, manufactures are not needing to make compromises. you get everything that a high end DSLR offers, in a much, much smaller package.I am very happy with this awesome deal.

Reviews.Title: GREAT FOR TRAVEL
Reviews.Author: V
Reviews.Content: if you going to travel, and walk a lot, this is the one to look for1) takes great pictures, as good as DSLR2) you can walk all day with it, not heavy or bulky3) size is perfect, will not get any attention from other peopleoverall its Better than i expected,

Reviews.Title: Not the newest model - but takes very good pics
Reviews.Author: Faxanadu
Reviews.Content: I got tired of the Point and Shoots, but was not ready to go full DSLR. This camera is amazing. Great shots in Auto mode and full manual control when you need it. I recommend that you pick up some literature beyond the manual to understand the full functionality of this great camera. Sure, there are newer models out there, but most use the same sensor. The kit lens is a bit slow, and the E-PL2 has a better kit lens, but I can;t say I have been let down by this lens and what it can get done. I am very happy with this camera and it serves as a great bridge between the point and shoot category and a full professional DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Handled a week of intense heat, travel and dust like a Champ
Reviews.Author: Semi-pro Video and Photo Shooter
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera right before a trip to a hot, dusty island country. I needed something smaller than my dSLR (Canon 7D), but I still needed excellent image quality. This camera was extremely easy to use, and performed well in just about every environment I used it in (90+ degree dusty villages, golden hour, twilight, sandy beaches, and it even got caught out in a small rain storm).The build quality of the camera itself is impressive, with a very solid, metal case. The image quality has been very good. I shot in manual mode about 80% of the time, and found the aperture and shutter settings quick and easy to use (even without a specific dial).I also purchased this camera for its purported video capabilities. I don't think it will replace a full size dSLR for video quality (certainly not the 7D or 5D), but it shot video that I don't mind editing together and showing people.I was also impressed by the battery life of this camera. 1 rechargeable battery allowed me to get through about 2 days of shooting (averaged about 3 hours of camera-powered-up time each day). I purchased two rechargeable batteries along with the camera and it's default battery, and this worked out perfect for the 10 days that I was out of the country.Cons: There are very few negatives to discuss here. I wish that this camera had a simple input connection to plug in a mic (as it is, you have to purchase an adapter that slides into the hot shoe). The default lens worked well, but, compared to the camera body, felt more fragile and looked like it could break more easily. It took a little while to figure out the specifics of video lighting control, as these were less intuitive. Even these controls weren't hard to figure out once I found the right menu.I would highly recommend this camera to pro's that want a smaller camera for travel, or for amateurs that want a higher quality camera without putting out $700 minimum for an entry level dSLR kit.

Reviews.Title: Great for Beginner Photographers and Travelers
Reviews.Author: Kyle May
Reviews.Content: I consider myself a prosumer photographer. I've owned several SLR and DSLR cameras including my current favorite which is a Nikon D700 with a variety of fast lenses. When I travel I don't like lugging those beasts around. These Micro Four Thirds camera systems are a great, smaller alternative. The E-PL1 in particular because you can pick one up at an amazing price right now (I paid under $300). I like this camera so much I bought one for my mother and mother-in-law and they both love them. My only complaint is that the manual aperture and shutter speed settings are not intuitive to adjust. I also wish it had an easy-to-use time-lapse setting. Other than that I love this camera. It's the one I have with me all the time.

Reviews.Title: Lots of fun and many features in small package at right price!
Reviews.Author: Sharon Reineman
Reviews.Content: Was on the fence in buying a DSLR after many years and wanting to get back into photography as I had been in my younger SLR years, having switched to a point and shoot type camera exclusively.  Nikon and Canon packages had my attention, until I read reviews on the Olympus Four-Thirds PEN cameras.  Between the lower price point and the wide choice of accessories and interchangeable lenses, in the end I chose the Olympus PEN E-PL1.  What tipped the scale in my final decision was that an acquaintance had the Olympus with him and was taking pictures with it at the top of a 4,000 ft mountain we'd just climbed during a club New Year's Day bicycle ride.  Basically, the recommendation was, he could easily bring the camera with him on activities out and about (such as bicycle rides), which he'd be less likely to do with a larger, heavier full-size DSLR, yet the image quality and versatility of the Olympus PEN E-PL1 was far superior to that of the portable point and shoot cameras.  Plus, it fit comfortably in my smaller hands.So that's it in a nutshell.  Pretty portable, light-weight but not "toy"-like, interchangeable lenses, good quality images, affordable.  After I ordered the camera, while I was waiting for it to arrive I watched the official Olympus marketing videos and became really excited about what this little baby can do.... the tag line, with which I concur, so far, is "the new powerfully simple Olympus PEN E-PL1, greater than the sum of its parts" ([...]), and I can't wait to try it all.  Together with the 40-150mm telephoto lens and accessory kit (wide-angle, zooms, filters, table-top tripod, etc, Olympus M. Zuiko Digital ED 40-150mm f/4.0-5.6 Lens For Olympus PEN E-PL1s, PEN E-P2, PEN E-P1 PEN, E-PL1 Digital SLR Cameras + SSE Accessory Kit. Includes: High Definition 0.45x Wide Angle Lens, 2x Telephoto HD Lens, 3 Piece Professional Filter Kit (UV...) I purchased separately, I'm on my way to a whole lot of fun!  Even joined up my (professional-photographer) sister's Photo Project Club, so hopefully my visually creative side will be jump-started after a long time of lying dormant.So far my one "complaint" with the design is that it has an "instant video" button which is placed right where your hand accidentally triggers it to go on next to the the grip on the back/side of the camera.  It's marketed as a feature, but i feel that it's a misguided piece of the otherwise nearly perfect overall design.  Luckily, there's a handy "delete" button for the unintentional ones, and there is probably a way to set the video button to locked, so it's not always going on at every touch (-:

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera
Reviews.Author: Keith Jackson
Reviews.Content: Every picture is beautiful.  No problems at all.  I don't miss not having a viewfinder.  I have had the camera for a year and still love it.

Reviews.Title: Great camera in a tidy little package!
Reviews.Author: Marilyn Armstrong
Reviews.Content: It was love at first touch. The moment my hands got onto this sweet baby, I knew I'd found my soul mate. Makes me sorry I spent all that money on the BIG Cannon (sic). Mind you, there are still things that I suspect will call for the bigger gun, but for most things I do, this is perfect.It is fast. Focuses fast. Recharges (using flash) fast. Has nice speed multiple-shot burst, though not quite as fast as the bigger camera. The anti shake is built into the camera and is not lens dependent, which is a fine thing for shaky old me. It is light and easy on my wrists. It packs up almost as small as my point and shoot, but oh my goodness how much better are the pictures it takes!!!!The controls are VERY simple. The manual that comes with it, unfortunately, may make the controls sound more complicated than they are. But it's a pretty decent manual even so and there was an obvious well-meaning attempt to include everything. Which, to fit it all in, they wrote in a kind of short hand that somethimes leaving me saying "huh?"In I-Auto, it is amazingly smart. They all SAY they are, but this one really IS. It will find a face in the crowd, literally. It is great for photographing my doll collection because it will find all the doll's faces and perform color correction at the same time ... without any assist from me, even using flash. Amazing.I wish it had a built in viewfinder, but I bit the bullet and ordered the electronic one that attaches to the hot shoe/utility port. I'm used to a viewfinder and it feels weird not having one.The LCD screen is plenty big and plenty bright.I have never seen so many choices of scene types or art filters ... and everything is easy easy easy to access. You don't have to navigate though layers of menus. It's right there.The controls fit in my hands.The camera feels solid and well built and biggest shock? The kit lens is fantastic! I did order one more longer lens, but that will cover it for me ... and at a price that does not break the bank. There are not yet enough lens choices, but because the 3/4 format lens mount has been standardized, you can use any lens from any 3/4 camera and it will fit. Now there's a concept the big manufacturers should consider adopting!!!In short, this is a great camera. REALLY super. I am very happy with it. Now I can take even MORE pictures. I'm sure glad I have a really huge hard drive!!I feel obliged to make a couple of additional comments:If you want metadata on photographs, you have to set it to on or it will not record. Most cameras record metadata automatically, but this doesn't. Just a warning.The manual is incomprehensible, at least to me. I was a tech writer for 30 years and I know a thing or two about manuals ... this one seems fine until you realize that the instructions don't make any sense. Finally gave in and bought "Olympus Pen E-PL1 for Dummies." I'm not a dummy, but a quick look at the info in this book made me realize that if I wanted to get the most from my camera, I needed instructions that made sense. The book does. The manual doesn't.The software that comes with the camera is awful and as far as I am concerned, useless. I removed it from my computer. Fortunately, between Lightroom and Photoshop, I don't need it. Don't count on using it for anything. Get software that works! Corel, Photoshop (or Elements) or something ... but don't count on using the stuff that comes with the camera!

Reviews.Title: SLR quality for cheap point and shoot price
Reviews.Author: Andre Portilho Maciel "Brazilian Dude"
Reviews.Content: The lens feels very cheap, but realy... for the price it will be impossible to get anything better with this picture quality.  I've taken fantastic professional looking pictures! A bit hard to get used to in the begining, but worth every penny! I highly recommend this camera!

Reviews.Title: Small camera, great images
Reviews.Author: The Bear "ambling across the cornfields at 15...
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera looking for one that was smaller and more portable than a DSLR but was also capable of great images.Pros:The image quality is great.Does well in low light.Small and easy to handle.Intuitive operations.Nice built-in flash for snapshots.Cons:A bit slow to save images to disk.Doesn't seem to do as well with action shots.No viewfinder (but I knew that when I bought it.I will probably add the VF3 viewfinder accessory.  I have also purchased the Fotodiox adapter that allows use of SLR manual lenses with this body.Summary:  Great quality, good camera for family photos, sightseeing, etc.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera for the size, bad low light AF
Reviews.Author: Mark Hambly "hammy"
Reviews.Content: I used to be a DSLR man, but I sold that when i realized i never carried it around anywhere due to bulk. Recently I decided to try out the micro 4/3's area of photography as it is similar to DSLR at a much smaller size.I would say that this is the camera that 90% of people who own low end DSLR's should have bought instead. What this camera can do for its size is mind boggling.The kit zoom lens is OK, but I quickly upgraded to the Panasonic 20mm f/1.7 FFL lens. This paid off immediately with faster AF, way better low-light, and just a level of picture quality that will fool anyone into thinking it was taken with a low-mid level DSLR.The biggest problem is using this camera in the dark. Generally i did not use the flash at all, but at night there was times where i wanted to but got frustrated enough to just not bother. There is no bulb-assist auto focus of any sort. The fast f/1.7 lens helps here, but overall it struggled in the dark. The flash is not very good on auto modes and can be a hassle to figure out the settings on your own.Overall for daytime photography such as scenery, people, and "things" this camera is amazing. But if you want to take this to a dark area and take pictures you are best looking elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Works Great--Even Better With  Panasonic 14-140mm f/4.0-5.8 Micro Four Thirds Lens
Reviews.Author: J. Weber
Reviews.Content: Great camera and sensor.  Great autofocusing (especially with firmware upgrade from Olympus). Surprisingly, when coupled with the Panasonic 14-140mm f/4.0-5.8 OIS Micro Four Thirds Lens, the optical image stabilization (OIS) in this lens is much better than that in the Olympus E-PL1 body.  About 50% more slow shutter shots were sharp for me with the Panasonic lens OIS than using the Olympus E-PL1 body OIS, using the same body/lens combination.  Video is also much more stable using the Panasonic lens OIS.  You can try it in a store and check it out for yourself--the difference is very visible even without taking a shot.  So, for me, the Olympus E-PL1 body and this Pansonic zoom lens has been the ultimate combination--best of both worlds.

Reviews.Title: DSLR quality, smaller package
Reviews.Author: Dr_LHA "Dr LHA"
Reviews.Content: Like many I had become unsatisfied with the quality of images I am getting from point and shoot cameras, and was looking to move up in the world to a "proper" (i.e. SLR style) camera, however like many others the main sticking point for me has always been the bulky nature of DSLR cameras and lenses. Because of this I had been watching the Panasonic/Olympus Micro Four Thirds system for a while as it promised to provide DSLR quality in a much smaller package. The E-PL1 for me was the tipping point in terms of price that I wanted to pay for a camera, along with the features I wanted. Also I'll freely admit this: I've been an Olympus guy all my life, and have typically been very happy with their products (although I'll admit I've owned a Sony P&S; as well, so I'm not exclusive).What's to like about the E-PL1: Its light, well constructed (of plastic admittedly, but it's more solid than most modern cameras I've used), the menu system is not too complex and gives learners a light intro into the art of SLR photography, the lenses are extremely small compared to their equivalents in the regular 35mm world, and the quality of photography I have achieved since buying this camera has been amazing compared to what I was capable with with a regular P&S.; 720p video adds to the package also, but it's really the size that is king here. You get a camera which is smaller and much less intimidating looking compared to what you're used to at this quality.Downside to this camera is clearly the lack of a viewfinder. People coming from SLR background will probably miss this the most, those of use who have grown used to using the LCD to shoot won't care that much, and I find the viewfinder works fine in daylight. There is an optional viewfinder available for purchase if you miss it though. I have not bothered.In all, very highly recommended for those who want to step up to "proper photography", but don't want to have to lug a massive camera bag around with you. I'd stress that this review is not a comparison review with other m4/3rds cameras, I have not owned any, mainly because their prices were out of my comfort zone.

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: Kat8nine
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera last week, I took it to a motocross race, and it was excellent. You don't have a lot of time to focus on  the riders as they go by and this camera kept up with my boyfriend's Canon T1i. He had a lens with a larger zoom and I was only using the lens it came with but it still took great pictures.The lack of a dial not being on the camera is not an issue for me, I have not had a DSLR before nor have I had a point and shoot with a dial, so I don't miss the dial. The functions to change the shutter speed, aperture, and other settings are easy enough to learn.I wanted the portability of a point and shoot but the picture quality of a DSLR and this camera is perfect for that. My last camera was a Lumix super-zoom camera from 8 years ago and this is a HUGE step up! I can't wait to take more pictures with my other lenses and filters.My only con about this camera is that the record video button is way to easy to press on accident. It's right above where you put your thumb and at the motocross race I would look at my camera and notice I've been recording the grass for a minute... but it's a minor flaw and does not affect the picture quality.

Reviews.Title: Second camera
Reviews.Author: Hyubie
Reviews.Content: I own a DSLR, but having 2 toddlers, I find that sometimes they are a bit much to lug around. On a recent trip, a family friend brought the E-PL1, and I had my DSLR. I initially thought he brought one of the point-and-shoots, but when he asked me to take a photo of him, I noticed it was a different kind of camera. My previous camera was an Olympus and I loved it, so I took note of the model he had. I waited for him to send his photos, and not surprisingly, I was impressed with the image quality. I researched quite a bit, took the leap, and bought this one.I was able to test it last weekend on another trip, and I'm glad I bought it.- The camera was small enough to carry around.- Image quality was very good. I don't think a regular person will know what shots were taken from this, and which ones were taken from a DSLR.- I didn't mind the (sometimes) slow auto-focus. It is not that slow, only slower compared to the DSLR.- Again, coming from DSLR, I did feel the slow lens when taking indoor shots, so I might opt for one of the faster lenses (Oly 17mm or Lumix 20mm).Overall, I will not be surprised if this is the camera that will join us on our next trips.

Reviews.Title: Camera review
Reviews.Author: Rjussell Sbrizza
Reviews.Content: I purchased this for my daughter it was a Christmas gift.  She absolutely loves it .  I purchased the same product a couple of years ago for my girlfriend and she loves hers.

Reviews.Title: Not to shabby at all.
Reviews.Author: Thomas Greber "thkpic"
Reviews.Content: I like this little guy. Pair it with the 45mm 1.8 and BANG....in business. Focusing isn't particularly fast but whatever. For the original price I'd probably say pass, but at the price it goes for now...YES YES YES. 1/2000's shutter speed is limited but you can get the ISO down fairly low.As far as AF, it doesn't hunt to bad either. It does seem to get a little wonky sometimes and not recognize what I"m trying to focus on, but with the zoom and manual focus I can avoid those few "issues" here and there. It feels great in the hands and looks even better in person.If you get this I HIGHLY recommend getting one of Olympus' primes. There simply sublime and with a little post processing you can really do some interesting things. All and all, not a bad little camera and I find the user menu stupid easy. I can't believe I can actually blur the background out on my pics. It's a keeper...so much so I now have two!!!By the way, I shot full frame and have 2k lenses on the side as well. This doesn't replace that but the pics are dang impressive for what it is. GREAT walkaround if your not pushing it and casual use.

Reviews.Title: Cheap fun to use and easy on my wallet
Reviews.Author: THE AUTISTIC WEREWOLF "Wolf"
Reviews.Content: Nice little camera a baby step up from a basic point and shoot but not a full fledged DSLR.  The camera is not great in low light but in all other ways the Olympus PEN E-PL1 12.3MP Live MOS Micro Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens meets my very basic needs. The camera was cheap fun to use and easy on my wallet.  I took one star off due to lots of noise in low light.  If you are outside or in a brightly lit room this camera is great.

Reviews.Title: Great value for amazing camera
Reviews.Author: Diego De la Cruz Bornholdt
Reviews.Content: I like taking photographs a lot, but haven't really spend on a good camera, like SLR. When this format of Micro 4/3 appear, i was really interested and it has been a great discovery so far.The camera let's you take so much better photographs than a point and shoot, and the size, weight and layout of the buttons gives you every control you need.The best part it's the capacity to and accesories, the kit lens its not very versatile, so i'm looking to buy another with more zoom. But takes great quality pictures. Also you can add a more powerful Flash or a ViewFinder that looks awesome.

Reviews.Title: great
Reviews.Author: vuhx
Reviews.Content: good camera, works as well as entry dslrs, maybe better? not very complicated, which I like. I'd check around for more comprehensive tech reviews but I like it and it takes great pictures.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Brooklin
Reviews.Content: My experience was excellent! I love this camera it's great for beginners and pros! Has alot of features that are easy to use. Art mode is great. Lens is awesome.

Reviews.Title: Love It!!!!
Reviews.Author: Adams, A.
Reviews.Content: Absolutely the best value for an interchangeable lens camera.  If you can still get one of the factory reconditioned ones for $200.  Great photos and if you desire, it has almost as many custom settings as my Nikon D-90.  For everyday use, I just grab this one and leave the Nikon at home. A fraction of the weight and bulk. :)

Reviews.Title: Im in love with this camera
Reviews.Author: eric ravnikar
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a trip that I was taking to Alaska. It shot incredible photos and was small enough to take everywhere. I have been using it now for about 6 months, and I still love it. It has a ton of features which make for some very creative photos, and it is easy enough for anyone to use like a normal camera, and has practically the same capabilities as a full sized DSL that cost twice as much.If you want to get into photograph beyond a point and shoot. This is the camera to have. You will love it.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: vincent himpe
Reviews.Content: Combining a large sensor diagonal , lots of pixels and an easy to use interface , coupled with the excellent micro four/thirds optics this gives as good an image as expense DSLR's without all the bulk. i bought this one as a spare. i have a second identical E-PL1 in an inderwater houseing for taking pictures while scuba diving.

Reviews.Title: PEN E-PL1: Not a P&S;, but beautiful photos
Reviews.Author: PJ
Reviews.Content: I bought the PEN E-PL1 to replace my broken bridge camera (Panasonic DMC-FZ7). I wanted to try something more advanced but I didn't want the bulk or weight of an SLR system. The technology in the MFT's intrigued me, and the Olympus fit my budget.My observations (after about 4 months).1. I cannot see anything at all on the LCD in full daylight, even with a shade. I'm amazed that some people can; kudos to them. I bought the VF-3 viewfinder which is less expensive than the VF-2 and works just fine. Factor in the cost of a viewfinder unless you try the camera before buying and you're sure that you won't need it.2. The kit lens is good for backyard shots, but you'll almost certainly want more lenses. I bought the least expensive Oly MFT telephoto ($300.); for my other lenses I'm planning to try a third-party 40.5 mm adapter ring that is supposed to work with MFT, but it hasn't arrived yet.3. Plan to buy a book on how to use the camera - there are a couple available. The menu system is sophisticated, powerful, and (IMO) non-intuitive. In addition, I've read that the Japanese-to-English manual doesn't mention everything that you can do with the MFT. I'm just beginning, and I expect that it will take me quite some time to thoroughly learn this camera.4. This MFT is slow, but not nearly as slow as it appears to be out of the box. I was shocked at first at the slow shutter lag and writing-to-card time in iauto, but that can be overcome. I eventually shot some sharp, crystal clear shots of my brother playing with my cats indoors by using stop motion. I caught feathers flying through the air and even the curve of a string while in fast motion. The speed between pictures in burst mode is still on the slow side, but not *that* slow.5. You cannot use this camera straight out of the box for action shots or low-light. I was disappointed with this camera at first b/c my Panny nearly always takes great shots in full-on auto mode and I thought that a few auto shots on the MFT would give me a good idea of the quality of this camera. Not so. You will likely have to make adjustments to shutter speed etc. to get decent shots. You will want to adjust the speed between shots. In iauto mode there is a helpful special menu, Live Guide, that allows easy basic changes. There's an excellent video on You-Tube that can help with this.6. One really good thing about this camera is that it is teaching me more about manual controls (and thus photography) b/c I like to shoot scenes for which the iauto mode is inadequate. With my Panny, I played but I mostly used auto.Summary: This is not a P&S; camera. Don't expect it to work perfectly in all situations right out of the box. Plan to invest some time and money in purchasing add-ons and learning the system. Your investments will be richly rewarded with excellent photographs (always bearing in mind that it is the quality of photographer, not the quality of the camera, that produces the best results).Plus five stars for picture quality, Live Guide in iauto mode, the many things that this camera can do.Minus one star for horrible instructions, badly placed buttons (especially the video button), useless LCD, no EVF built in, outrageous prices for EVF and adapter rings, user-unfriendly menus, and slow burst speed (even after adjustment).

Reviews.Title: Olympus pen pl-1 camera
Reviews.Author: Keith H. Wooten
Reviews.Content: Best buy for the money. Fairly simple to use, excellent quality and build. Shot my first photos at the state fair using the art filters. Wow what great results. Can't wait to use with the 40-150mm lens.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for Beginner or Advanced Photographer
Reviews.Author: Bill D.
Reviews.Content: My wife recently lamented that her point and shoot camera didn't meet her expectations anymore and she began to revert to her iPhone for her picture taking needs. Granted, I don't have a problem with camera phones in general. They're great for emailing pics, but lousy if you decide to make a print. I think my wife was beginning to feel that the limitations of the camera phone were seriously outweighing the convenience of it and mentioned to me recently how she wanted a "real" camera. She has limited photography knowledge, but was interested in getting a camera that could take decent photos, had some creative flexibility and could grow with her. She hinted about getting a DSLR, but I knew that this would be a BIG learning curve, and didn't think she would make the commitment of lugging a big camera around.After nosing around a couple of photography forums, I came across the Olympus E-PL1. I'm familiar with the Olympus brand back in the days when I was an avid film photographer and knew they made nice, compact cameras with decent lenses. I know that there are newer versions of this model, but the price was too good to pass-up, so I sprung on it because I wanted her to have a nice camera for our vacation.I have to admit, this camera has definitely exceeded my expectations in terms of image quality and depth of features. The four thirds format which Olympus has pioneered as well as the large MOS sensor and friendly, yet rich camera controls really has pushed the PL1 into new and exciting creative possibilities that you just don't see in most point-and-shoots. The controls are for the most part, very logically laid out and have extra features for both the experienced and novice photographers (like the Live Guide controls which greatly simplify image tweeking). What's also nice is that you can use any third party micro four thirds or four thirds camera lenses with this body. The only downside that I see is the lack of a built in eyepiece and how sometimes it will search a little longer to get an object in dim light in focus. Other than that, this baby is a winner.Granted, my wife is still learning how to operate the camera, but she too is amazed at the quality photos this camera produces. And now, I'm a little jealous that she has a camera that blows my trusty, five year old Canon G series camera away.

Reviews.Title: Great value in a midlevel camera
Reviews.Author: JBowl0101
Reviews.Content: I replaced an aging, battered digital Rebel with this camera, and could not be more pleased. Great images, reasonably good video. Fast for multiple shots, as high as 3200 ISO lets me shoot indoors without flash even with the kit lens. The kit lens is nothing spectacular, but does the job for a good all-around workhorse. The camera has proven to be durable.My only complaint is that the user interface required me to open the manual to figure out how to set ISO.. but that was it. :-) I would absolutely recommend it as a step up from a pocket camera, for backpacking and hiking, etc.

Reviews.Title: Great upgrade from P&S; camera
Reviews.Author: Alex
Reviews.Content: If you are the one1. who does not want to carry heavy and bulky DSLR camera but you want a DSLR-like photo quality2. who is a budget-minded buyer like me always looking for a value for money product3. who wants to start learning photography without investing so much on pricey camerasthen, Olympus E-PL 1 is definitely for you.I am very satisfied with this camera so far. There are some downsides like slow auto focus, button control for aperture and shutter speed, etc, but I can live with that.Do not be confused by its low price tag. It is really a great camera.(This camera came with an international warranty)

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera for this price.
Reviews.Author: Ani
Reviews.Content: This camera can take pictures as good as any entry level SLR cameras. For all the novices out there, please pick this camera over those bulky SLRs. Don't just blindly get an SLR camera because you saw some friend of yours get an SLR and it clicked good pictures. Technically speaking, SLRs need not have better lenses or better sensors. They are only better (even that is arguable) at showing you a real preview through the viewfinder. If you are not a viewfinder sort of a camera man and are an LCD screen sort of a person then please don't waste money on an SLR. Get an MILC (like this one). Its more compact and takes equally good pictures. I love the photo quality on this one. I have  Nikon D3200 and I honestly, think that pen epl1 is a better camera because of less bulk.

Reviews.Title: excellent camera
Reviews.Author: T. quach
Reviews.Content: Have it for about 1 year. Excellent picture quality. Very easy to use and the manual focus is extremely manageable for every single points you need in your viewable area. Very happy with it

Reviews.Title: Great Carry Camera
Reviews.Author: JRD
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for carrying when you don't want to carry a DSLR.  The picture quality is much better than a point and shoot and so close to a DSLR that I can't tell the difference.  The controls are okay so long as you are willing to go through the menus.  For what I wanted a super point and shoot this works for me.  The autofocus is not as fast as a DSLR but okay for snap shots and vacation pictures.  If you want to do sports take along a DSLR.  I also have the 40 to 150mm lens.  It works great if the light is good.  That is what I expected given the f-stop settings.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: David Hammett Jr.
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera less than a month before going to Alaska. I may never learn to use all the functions but I came home with some great pictures. The software ("ib") that comes from Olympus with the camera is not my favorite but it is usable. I will find something better when I have time. The only negative is that the accessories are expensive; I will do without for now even though I have several OM SLR lenses.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: It is an awesome camera with a DSLR working style OLYMPUS rendered. Its pictures are superb, and detail within this price range. The camera's metering is very dependable, in most of the circumstances for me. The excellent JEPG and RAW compatibility files in-camera, means many good qualities. Overall, the users in this price range get the most of DSLR attributes with excellent image quality.

Reviews.Title: Toy Camera at bargain price
Reviews.Author: Max Chiu
Reviews.Content: I got the camera at HK$2,000 (US$25X) a few days ago. It really an outstanding camera at this price range. I own a lot of camera from compact, prosumer (G11 and GDR III) to DSLR (D7000). Not to repeat pro and con listed in the professional reviews, I would like to stress I use the camera as an experiment or 'toy camera'.I got a pk to m43 adapter and can use my old Pentax lens (manual focus, of course). It make a lot of fun. Also I got a Samyang 7.5mm fisheye lens (HK$2,250, US$28X) and shot 'good' fisheyes photos. It is just a fraction of price of other 'serious' fisheyes lens. I going to get some CCTV lens as well as pinholes. There are a lot of toy lens, accessories designed for M43. Some of them produce great effect at low price.It will not be my serious camera at today standard. But it is an excellent 'toy camera'!

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera with limits
Reviews.Author: M. Elek "Just a guy"
Reviews.Content: Update: After about five months with this camera, I still am very pleased with my purchase. I've taken several thousand photos in all different kinds of lighting situations. I use the white balance options frequently.For those who like a viewfinder, the VF-2 is an excellent option. I use it about 95% of the time.Images are a bit noisy at the higher ISOs, but this shouldn't be a surprise, given the size of the sensor. I've made several "how to" videos, and the quality is very good, although for some reason they won't import into Sony Vegas Studio.I have a sizable number of manual focus lenses, so at some point I should pick up some of the adapters.It's a great camera, and I haven't found it lacking in any way so far.ORIGINAL REVIEW:Overall, I am very pleased with this camera. I like using it, and haven't bumped into too many limitations. The autofocus definitely struggles in low light, and then you'll have to switch to manual focus.Image stabilization, the self-cleaning sensor and Live View are very good features.What I liked:- Price. To be truthful, I bought this model because of its low cost. I haven't been disappointed. I think it's one of the best deals in compact system cameras (CSCs).- Small size. Feels great in your hands. Buttons mostly are where they need to be. I found the interface to be fine. But maybe because I had owned an Olympus Evolt 500 at one time.- Build quality: Everything feels tight. There is some heft to the camera, which gives it a feeling that it's not your typical point and shoot.- Rear screen. OK, so it's just 2.7 inches or whatever. The screen is excellent with such a high refresh rate that it seems almost like a video camera.- Exposure. So far, I think that the camera gets the exposure right more often than it misses.- One-button video record. I haven't made many videos, but this definitely made it much easier and avoided doing the usual "turn control knob to video" and then press shutter button to start.What I didn't like:- Lots of button-pushing required. I think this might be endemic to all Asian camera makers, as they seem fascinated by adding buttons. And to quickly access certain controls, you really have to memorize the sequence.- LCD screen in sunlight. This isn't limited to this camera. I bought the VF-2 viewfinder, which is excellent with this camera, especially for those of us who don't like holding a camera at arm's length or have eyes that have difficulty focusing on close objects (such as LCD screens).- The art filter software grinds the camera to a halt. Screen refresh slows dramatically to the point that it feels like one of those really early digital cameras from the 1990s. This was a bit disappointing.Other- Shutter noise. I erroneously was hoping for P&S; noise levels. I didn't realize that it had an actual focal-plane shutter. This was my fault.- Memory card requirements. For larger cards, make sure that they are Class 6 or higher. Slower cards will error out upon format or possibly not correctly record your image. I ran into this same problem with a Pentax K10D.

Reviews.Title: Takes good pictures, not most versatile
Reviews.Author: rr
Reviews.Content: I have had the Olympus PL1 and a Sony HX9V for a couple of months now so I have had a good opportunity to compare them.  I bought the Sony mainly as a hiking and family occasion camera.  The zoom range, macro focus, low light level performance, and pocket size are all I could expect.  I then tried to use it to take some coin pictures and was very disappointed.  With no RAW mode there was very poor fine detail.  The Sony has more megapixels than it can focus sharply.I bought the Olympus for the coin pictures and the detail it can achieve is outstanding.  It does not focus close up so I tried extension tubes.  The focus outside of a very small spot in the center was very fuzzy.  I tried close up lenses.  At first I had serious chromatic aberration at the edges.  Change in lighting and camera angle solved that.  The coin pictures are very nice.  I can see more detail than by looking at the coins even with a magnifying glass.  So how does it compare with the Sony?  The Sony wins in all areas except for taking sharp pictures.  Sony goes hiking and to get togethers, Olympus stays home and takes coin pictures.I have on Olympus OM2 and 4 associated lenses.  I was expecting their large lenses and multiple elements to out perform the stock lens that came with the PL1.  Much to my surprise the stock lens out performed all the old lenses in terms of sharpness

Reviews.Title: Nice camera for the price/size
Reviews.Author: Dave H
Reviews.Content: I was a little disappointed when I received this camera. In fact, I almost returned it. The build feels kind of cheap and plastic, I was used to my sturdy DSLR. Plus, the controls are not easy to use, you have to go through confusing menus to adjust even basic settings. On top of that, the autofocus is kind of slow, and pretty much useless in low light.So why did I keep it? Well, I started taking it around with me, and it was so much easier to carry than my DSLR. A lot less conspicuous for street photography, too. And since it was relatively inexpensive, I didn't feel bad taking it on more risky shoots while hiking and whatnot. Plus, the image quality is pretty great.I see this as a photographer's point-and-shoot. Sacrifice control for smaller size while maintaining high quality photos.

Reviews.Title: A little gem of a camera!
Reviews.Author: Gerald Fischetti "Jerry"
Reviews.Content: I just recently purchased my Pen E-PL1 and love it. Though I have not had it long, I particularly like the e-portrait feature and the art filters. I took a photo of my wife in natural light at home and used e-portrait and you would think it was taken in my studio when I had my pro photography business. Learning something new everyday and enjoying the experience.

Reviews.Title: Great bridge camera, photo quality and build construction for the price
Reviews.Author: Enrique
Reviews.Content: It is a nice little camera with a lot of potential in the right hands.I adore it because im learning almost everything i need to know about digital photography. To take great pictures you need to start learning the basics, exposure, aperture, shutter speed, focal lenght and so on. This camera is great for learning and playing with manual controls, and it'll let you take awesome professional like pictures as long as you apply the right technics. Because of these i consider it an awesome bridge camera, but trust me if you're going to stick to the iAuto mode you dont need this. Simply you wont be using all the potential this camera has to offer.

Reviews.Title: You've got to learn how to use it!
Reviews.Author: kmac
Reviews.Content: I'm happy with the camera, but find that it doesn't always take photos that are as good as the little canon p&s; I used to have, because I'm not particularly adept at working it or choosing the settings.PROS:There will NEVER be a "lens jam" EVER! (I've lost 4 cameras to this error, why I went with a micro 4/3)Much more compact than a standard DSLRDecent zoom - I debated buying another lens but this is sufficient for my needsPhoto options I like: pop art, soft touch, etc.Easy to work menu options - I was a little nervous about this because I've owned only canons for close to 20 yearsPriceCONS:As other reviewers said, it isn't the best at taking photos of moving kids (sensor issues?).  Unfortunately for me, that's basically what I'm taking pictures of.  There is one setting I use that's a sports option that does a decent job, but I find that there are still more pictures with movement blur than with my point-and-shoot.The battery charger is bulky - but you can buy a compatible, generic wall plug-in for about $5Though smaller than a DSLR, it's definitely not a pocket-sized cameraFor the price, I don't think you can beat this camera.  I know it's technology from a couple of generations ago, and likely the PEN E-PL3 is a better camera, but I was thrilled to get it for about what I'd pay for a higher-end p&s.;  Like I said, I've lost 4 cameras in 6 years to the dreaded lens jam, and wanted to spend my money on something that might last longer than 13 months.  The camera has a really solid feel and I think once I learn better how to use it I will be thrilled, not just happy to have it.

Reviews.Title: Awsome Value
Reviews.Author: Geeves Beham
Reviews.Content: I am in the horticulture business, and select new varieties to be grown. As I am in the business of visual asthetics, a good camera is critical. I wanted top quality pictures and ease of use. After reading many reviews and comparing pricing, I chose the E-PL1.I have been thrilled with this choice. When shooting in full auto mode I can get excellent work shots very quickly, and (critical for my work) true to color. The high res JPEG is excellent. I compare photos from this camera to ones taken by a Cannon Eos T3i and other than the file size, the pictures are as good or better. The compact size is great as I travel extensively. I have been pleased with the battery life, despite some reviews. Added a fast 16GB card and I can shoot all day. Took my kids to the Aquarium, and Zoo and let my 10 yr old daughter shoot, she took some amazing shots, and had fun with Art modes, getting some great results. I'm for the most part a point and shoot user that needs excellent quality. For this purpose the E-PL1 is exceptional. And for a great price as well.

Reviews.Title: The best camera bargain out there
Reviews.Author: just_aris
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I was tired of retouching pictures on photoshop for my point and shoot camera but I didn't want the bulk of a DSLR.  While I was deciding to buy a good camera, my friends and I went hiking and one of my friends slipped off a rock and fell into a stream - with her DSLR.  I would not want to be that person with the wet and broken $700 camera.  So bottom line, I wanted something powerful, cheap, easy to use, and would fit me need - capturing memories and images of family and friends.  I didn't need something that would make my pictures look like they could go into a National Geographic magazine and I wasn't going to enter any photography competitions either.  Let's be real.  So I was doing my research and the Olympus pen was one of the most recommended 4/3 cameras out there.  Great settings and programs and interchangeable lenses sold me to it.  The one that sealed the deal though was this ad: [...]So I bought the Olypus Pen and I've never looked back.  I've had this camera for six months now and I absolutely love it.  It does everything I want it to do and more.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for those who don't want a DSLR
Reviews.Author: Luvinhistory
Reviews.Content: I had a point and shoot that failed and was in the market for a new camera.  I looked at friends DSLRs and I liked the picture quality but there were features I knew I would never use and they tended to be a bit heavy.  I stumbled on the Micro Four Thirds format in Best buy loved the cameras but not the price tag.  So I looked here at amazon and found this Olympus PEN E-PL1 price was right where I wanted to spend, so I followed my Friend Kat's advise and looked it up with CNET and the reviews were great on this camera.  When the camera arrived I charged the battery, 3.5 hrs on the button charge time.  Then I took some test pictures turned out great.  I do advise getting higher class SD cards for speed in reading to the card.  Very good camera.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic and simple.
Reviews.Author: texas mike "I eat rocks"
Reviews.Content: First off, this was a gift. I got this for my girlfriend for Christmas this year.She absolutely loves it. She wanted something better than a point and shoot and has no experience with a SLR of any kind.She read through the manual thoroughly while the battery was charging, and was off and running as soon as it was ready.It produces beautiful pictures and has an easy User Interface that she had no problem picking up.I would suggest this to anyone new into digital photography, or any professional looking for a space saving backup.The seller contacted me the day I purchased this to inform me that they were out of the color I ordered, but it wasn't for me so the gold color ended up working out just fine.

Reviews.Title: Well Worth A Look
Reviews.Author: Charles Percoco "Wildcatbuff"
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera about three weeks now and am more than happy with it.To the average person outdoor pics will look about the same as a quality point and shoot does on a computer screen. But where this camera really shines is in its ability to take quality photos in low light without a flash. Great for pet pics who normally get the "Devil Glow Eyes" with a flash. Terrific for little kids blowing out candles on their Birthday Cake using just the candle light. If you are a traveller you'll love the fact you will get nice shots in those places like Old Churches and what not that don't allow flash usage. Held back on a five star rating because HD movie mode while very good is limited to 7 minute clips and are recorded in AVI not AVCHD,which means in most cases you will have to convert the file to record onto a DVD to play on your Blu-Ray player. This is an older model and heavily discounted now,you can find a deal for a bit more than a mid priced p&S; and get a great camera in the process. Word of warning though,you may get the lens bug and start to get the urge to play with other lenses,most of which will come close to the cost of the camera itself.A nice retro look,I ordered the black leather skin for the front to give it more of that '70s Rangefinder look. A home run by Olympus!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Xty
Reviews.Content: This little number takes some great pictures. If you expect this to be a point & shoot, it is not. You need to take the time to read the manual and watch or read some photog tutorials about it. Get comfortable with the settings. Once you do all that your pics will be amazing. If you don't want to take the time, stick to a point & shoot.

Reviews.Title: Sharper, more pleasing images than my big expensive Canon DSLR
Reviews.Author: Macuser
Reviews.Content: My compact sized and inexpensive Olympus E-Pl1 delivers the crispy sharp landscape images with vivid, yet true to life colors that my big, heavy, expensive Canon T3i is incapable of.  I will be selling the Canon and using the E-Pl1 full time.I could have avoided the fustration I experienced with the Canon if I had carefully compared the sample images of the Olympus PEN cameras vs the Canon and Nikon DSLR's at [...]They show the PEN camera landscape images are sharper and more detailed with truer, real life colors.  It is simply a fallacy to think using a big, heavy, macho looking DSLR assures the best possible image sharpness, detail and color.

Reviews.Title: Great upgrade
Reviews.Author: amazon dude
Reviews.Content: I got this camera because I was tired of the image quility of the point and shoot camera, and I wanted something that I could change lenses.  I never got this kind of pictures from a point and shoot.  I still would rather have a DSLR, but this camera is definately affordable and takes great pictures.  The kit lens that comes with it takes good pictures, but doesn't have great zoom.  It has a pretty wide angle though.  It does take pretty good pictures in low light, but it takes a little adjusting with the settings.  This is a great camera, and would buy another one if I could.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful images
Reviews.Author: KittenCamaro
Reviews.Content: If you aren't ready to shell out the big bucks for an entry level SLR but want high quality images then look no further!This camera is for you: you want superb image quality with very low noiseThis camera is not for you: you do a lot of high speed shootingPositives - easy to use right out of the box without much knowledge, fun art effects like a pinhole camera, interchangeable lens for the more advancedNegatives - a bit slow if you do high speed shooting, no built in viewfinder (available separately)

Reviews.Title: Loving it!
Reviews.Author: S. Ignjatovic
Reviews.Content: So far, I am loving this camera. The colors are awesome, lag time doesn't exist (or, if it does, it is not noticeable AT ALL), video is good, art filters are fun to use. It is not that bulky. I have never owned an SLR camera before, and I now am so happy I haven't ordered one, because this one's size is on the verge of convenient size, when it comes to traveling and taking pictures. The quality of pictures to me looks like SLR quality. I recommend it to everyone who wants to upgrade from point-and-shoot cameras, who wants to learn more about photography, and who wants to use it as a travel camera, as well.

Reviews.Title: Happy photo bug....
Reviews.Author: JusPeachy
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  Wish it came with a slightly larger zoom lens but will have to do for now.  The difference in the pictures (this vs. reg.digital) are clear immediately.  I especially love the fact that I have the ability to let it auto decide settings or do a manual takeover :)  Gives me plenty of room to learn the slr features while allowing me the ability to take those need now pics.  Only downside I saw, like I said before, the zoom lens that comes with the camera (14-42mm) just won't cut it for more than a good landscape or portrait.

Reviews.Title: Great Image Quality, interface not up to E-P2
Reviews.Author: Joseph L. Kashi
Reviews.Content: Image quality is really excellent, at least if you use first class prime lenses like the Panasonic 20mm F1.7 pancake, and the Olympus 35mm F3.5 and 50mm F2 macro lenses (along with the MMF-2 external viewfinder.)I do have the Canon S90 and G series cameras that another reviewer mentioned favorably and they are good cameras.  However, the images made by the E-PL1 are definitely higher quality, with much better sharpness and dynamic range, and significantly better high ISO capabilities.  After all, the sensor is much larger.Yes, this is a somewhat slow focussing camera but auto-focus seems more accurate than some higher end dSLR cameras that I've used.  Because of the very weak anti-aliasing filter, images made with good optics like those listed above are as sharp as any digital images that I've seen, regardless of price or brand.  Dynamic range is a bit of an issue with noticeable highlight clipping.  However, shooting in  RAW+JPEG and under-exposing slightly seems to help a lot.  Color quality is very nice in all file formats.Given its image quality and sensor size, this camera is definitely small enough and light enough, much more so than any comparable dSLRs.  Due to the availability of high-grade optics, system flexibility and image quality is better than one-trick ponies ( oops - one good lens compact "system" cameras like the recently introduced Samsung and Sony models.Some of the adjustment issues can be minimized by using the "super" menu although setting the rear "OK" function button to bring up a full adjustment menu is not well-explained in the manual and is not an intuitively obvious menu item.Handling is much improved by adding the very nice VF-2 viewfinder, if you can get it at a reasonable price.  That way, you can either have really good handling when desired or a very compact camera if you mount a pancake lens.Overall, though, the new Olympus E-PL2 seems like a more usable camera for $100 more, with an adjustment wheel and a much less wobbly zoom lens.  The older zoom lens is actually pretty sharp but its wobbly second inner barrel does not inspire confidence when extended.  The new MSC version II lens solves that problem.

Reviews.Title: Great Value
Reviews.Author: Patrick O'Brien "Patrick"
Reviews.Content: Great camera with great options. Easy to use for a starter! HD Video is great.

Reviews.Title: Fun
Reviews.Author: Grendel
Reviews.Content: The camera is aimed at P&S; people like me. I wanted better pictures from a bigger sensor in a camera i can carry like a P&S.; It does that, and it is fun and instructive to use. You can adjust the light, colour, depth of field, &c.; of a proposed snap and see the results in screen in real time. There are hundreds of other preferences to tinker with.One problem is the cover for the usb connector. It seems it could snap. Overall the camera feels solid and comfortable in my hand. Mac users will need to download Olympus Master 2 to process raw files, and find the free app to update firmware. Look in the [...] forum discussions for info and sample pictures.I am delighted with picture quality of this camera.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera, but know what to expect!
Reviews.Author: Atomic Grrrrrl
Reviews.Content: If you're a major photo enthusiast like I am, then you've been probably frustrated by the lack of options when it comes to being able to buy a moderately-priced, lightweight camera with decent image output. Either you're stuck with having to buy a super chunky DSLR that weighs 1000 pounds or you have to shell out at least $400 for a prosumer point and shoot that, by virtue of being a point and shoot, doesn't give you a lot of creative control.Enter micro four-thirds. The Olympus Pen EP-L1 was my first foray into this type of camera, because I was sick and tired of the either/or of DSLRs and compacts. I wanted a moderately inexpensive camera that could take better than average pictures and be easy to carry, so I decided to take the plunge with MFT.Having finally taken it, I'm happy to say that I was so thrilled with the Olympus Pen EP-L1 that I immediately sold off my much older DSLR so I could purchase more accesories for it.So what's got me so excited exactly?CLASSIC LOOK, WEIGHT, AND FEELThe Olympus Pen-EP L1 was the first digital camera I ever held that felt like an analog camera. People who used to shoot film will know exactly what I'm talking about. Digital cameras have this toy-like and plasticky feel to them. Everything about this Oly feels like you're using a real camera, right down to the clicking shutter sound, metal accents on the body, and vintage appearance.The weight is just about "right", too. The Pen EP-L1 isn't as light as a compact but not as rock heavy as a DSLR. Portability is a breeze-- just remove the lens, and you can easily slip both into the pockets of your backpack or the inside pocket of your jacket or coat without issue.KIT LENS- SURPRISINGLY GOODI was very pleased with the kit lens; I actually found it performed much better than the one for my old DSLR, which was hit or miss. Images were sharp, and I was finally able to get a clear handheld shot of these votive candles in dim lighting from St. Patrick's Cathedral after years of trial-testing other cameras (see my customer images, which is posted under this version-- Olympus PEN E-PL1 12.3MP Live MOS Micro Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens Digital Camera with 14-42mm f/3.5-5.6 Zuiko Digital Zoom Lens (Slate Blue)). I was able to also take fairly sharp pictures inside of St. Paddy's (of course with some bracing), which was impressive.COLORS- RICH AND WARM TONEDThe colors are outstanding in this camera, very reminiscent of Fujifilm-- very rich, warm, and true to life without being oversaturated, bland, or unnatural. I was really knocked back when I saw the first pictures I took. With previous cameras, I've always remembered first impressions being disappointing. This was the first camera where I was like, "Wow, look at the colors! Nice!"JAM-PACKED WITH CREATIVE FEATURES AND CONTROLThe Oly is an enthusiast's dream. Not only is there full manual control, there are many interesting filter and camera effects you can apply, such as "tilt shift", pop art, panorama, and multiple exposure.USABILITYI've heard people complain about the buttons and dials of this camera. I'm surprised, because I found it incredible intuitive. I guess what's throwing everyone off is that the buttons are laid out so differently from a standard camera. (For example, there is a separate button for film and video). There are some other oddities similar to this. But playing around with the camera for a couple of hours, I got used to it very quickly.PRICEAre ya kidding me? This is one of the few micro 4/3ds you can get at this price point (the other being the Panasonic Lumix DMC-GF3 12 MP Micro 4/3 Compact System Camera with 3-Inch Touchscreen LCD and 14-42mm Zoom Lens (Black) at the time of this writing). At under $300 you can't beat it!A FEW CAVEATSAs great as the Pen EP-L1 is, there are some issues you'll want to know about.Number one, the SD slot-slash-battery compartment is cheap and poorly designed. Not only is it cumbersome to fish out the SD card, the cover (which clunkily swings open at a 90 degree angle) is an accident just waiting to happen. (I can just see one day a fumble for the memory card resulting in a hand accidentally knocking back against the cover and damaging it). I've lent my cameras to my father before (who's kind of clumsy) and would to other people. I definitely wouldn't lend this camera to someone because of this issue, because I can just imagine them handing it back with a sheepish grin and going, "Hehehe... uh, I had a little whoopsy!
