Sorry!"Number two, the flash is a little odd. You have to remember to unlock it first before you can use it. Not a big deal, but it takes some getting used to.Number three, although there are quite a few cool filter effects in the Pen ("diorama, pop, etc"), you need patience to use them. This is because the screen preview lags horribly when shooting. So as nice as these filters are to have, you're probably better off just shooting your image normally and altering it later in an image editor.Number four, you can only shoot HD video for 7 minutes at a time.Number five, the back cap to the kit lens is very flimsy and easy to lose, because it doesn't twist or screw on-- it pops on, making it easy to "pop off."Number six (and lastly), don't expect miracles with this camera. Let me put it this way-- you'll definitely get better image output and low noise from the Pen than any point and shoot under $400. However, the performance won't equal that of a DSLR. Noise starts showing up in shadowy areas at 100 ISO. And pictures taken on overcast days, fuhgeddaboutit. Noise and speckling all around, even at 200 ISO.The good news is that it looks like the natural grain of analog film, especially when tweaking settings. The bad news is that if you were hoping to buy this camera with the expectation that it would be like your current DSLR, except "lighter", you're out of luck.So basically, get this camera if you're looking to upgrade from a point and shoot in terms of better image quality and creative control. But don't get this to switch over from a DSLR, because low light level performance still isn't quite "there" yet. It's not a deal breaker in terms of noise-- just saying that for someone hoping it'll match that of a DSLR, you'll be a bit disappointed.

Reviews.Title: I'm an amateur to photography
Reviews.Author: Michelle
Reviews.Content: Photography? Not exactly my forté. But hey! I like to take pictures now & then so I've been strolling around the internet for a good, well built, high quality picture taking camera for quite some time now. Well folks, this is it. Not only does this camera take amazing pictures, it's so simple to use. It is a great compact size, and is light weight. It also has these cool art filters that you can use to make things a little more interesting. Bottom line, I love this camera so far. You just can't beat the price. So if you want to play photographer for the day & be successful at it, consider this camera your new pal.

Reviews.Title: Happy Mommy to be!
Reviews.Author: drivera89
Reviews.Content: My husband purchased the Olympus PEN E-PL1 for me to get some great shots of our baby nephews and our baby girl who is not due until December. We have had it for a week now and I LOVE it!! It has so many great options!!! Its easy to use and small enough to fit in a camera bag. It was the perfect step up from a point n shoot. The only downfall of the camera is it does not have a black and white setting. It has a grainy film setting which is black and white but also grainy. So if I ever want traditional black and white photos I will need to shoot in color and edit them to black and white. To me this is no big deal! It was well worth the price!! Other "beginner" slr cameras I considered were up to 3 times the amount. At 280 dollars I am happy to have such a great product! I also should add that I was very intimidated by the pop-up flash, but after using the camera it is not a big deal at all! The flash is still automatic you just have to press a button to pop the flash up while taking photos to make sure the flash goes off when needed. We had our professional photographer look at it today and even she was impressed by the amount of options on this camera! It may be a little more than we need but I will grow into it and learn how to take advantage of all the options. It's a great product!! I would recommend this to any beginner photographers or soon to be mom's!Olympus PEN E-PL1 12.3MP Live MOS Micro Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens Digital Camera with 14-42mm f/3.5-5.6 Zuiko Digital Zoom Lens (Black)

Reviews.Title: A fun, easy-to-carry camera system
Reviews.Author: Active Media
Reviews.Content: I gotta be honest, I'm not a professional photographer, or even come close to calling myself an amateur photographer. I wanted something light, not a point-and-shoot, but something that can get me excited about shooting outdoors. I felt like this was the camera worth investing, in that it's performance was pretty up-to-date, looked beautiful, and had reputation of great quality. The ability to change lens sold me completely, and it's the perfect hybrid of the two worlds. The lens is great for starting out, and I'm slowly going to be saving for a fancier lens later on.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for those Legacy Lens You might Have
Reviews.Author: Ctman2
Reviews.Content: I have a Panosonic FZ28 megazoom camera and several more conventional Olympus digital cameras but I have been a photographer through the film age and accumulated a system camera from Nikon; the Nikomatte with lots of lens and accessories including microscope and telescope adapters.  I wanted to use these legacy lens and accessories with a digital camera and this camera is the perfect digital back for me as well as a near DSLR camera too when you get an adapter which are available for almost any legacy camera on the Internet.I quickly found out that legacy lens are not as sharp as the newer digial ones and of course are much bigger and heavier.  I did all kinds of testing which I like to do and got that bug out of my system since the only usable ones were the microscope, telescope, and 50mm prime lens that provided either unique function or a quality picture.I have always had a soft spot for Olympus cameras and this one did not disappoint me.  The best camera is the one you have with you and that is always the lightest and smallest one; I usally have a camera with me all the time.  This one is the best compromise I have tried so far combining near DSLR and portability with HD video.Like anything else if you honestly define your requirements and then look for a camera to match you will be ahead of the game; many people are in denial and have some requirements that are based on what others seem to want.Overall I think the vast majority of people who want something more than a P&S; would be very happy with this camera and I highly recommend it for the price point.

Reviews.Title: Best camera around
Reviews.Author: geprieto
Reviews.Content: This camera is just too close to be perfect. I originally had my sights on the pen e-p2 and the panasonic G1, but I decided on the e-pl1. Not because of the price, but for the flash (not present on the e-p2) and the bulb mode (limited to 4 minutes on the G1). The build quality is excellent, and is more heavy than I imagined. The sensor quality is VERY good! I had a Canon SX before, DSLR, and the quality is even better, especially at high ISO modes. And just as they say the auto mode of this camera really works. I used to shoot almost always in Aperture priority mode, or at least in Program. With this gadget I almost never leave the auto mode. True, I do photography for hobby, but I know my way around cameras.The only issue I have with it is that for now there is no cheap lens to buy with a high field of view. Since it is micro 4/3 you get 2x of the focal distance, so the kit lens performs like a 28-84mm, and you will find yourself walking quite some steps back to get your subjects into the picture. But the video mode on its own helps to forget this. Before this camera I never shoot video. Now I find my photo albums are a multimedia mix, since the steps form one to the other almost disappear with this unit.If you got tired of carrying around your bag with the DSLR, lenses, flash, etc this is a MUST BUY.

Reviews.Title: E-pl1 for video, a few weeks of use, my thoughts.
Reviews.Author: Ink Stain
Reviews.Content: I have an Olympus 520, and a lot of manual lenses, and adapters, so I bought the E-pL1 for video, and adapters for Nikkor and M42 screw mount Takumar's so I can use them for video lenses. I have old Cannon lenses, but not the adapter yet for them so I cannot talk about that, but you can use most any lens. The adapters are fine, focus is always an issue, but live mode helps on a tripod in bright light, hand held its a guess due to LCD washout. You can use the old school stuff of street shooting to a set distance. Using the manual lens distance scale. The shooting modes and color control for the camera to its 720p HD level of quality is outstanding for video use, as long as you know that DSLR video is going to be on a tripod to avoid the jello effect, and that the in body stabilization available for manual lenses, which works well for stills, is not the same as the electronic stabilization for the video mode, on a tripod you can get great color and a lot of choices. Since I am interested in studio video and animation, shake is not much of an issue. I like the size, kit lens, color, modes, and art mode color. I have the external sound adapter, and its very useful. In manual mode with external sound, pre focus set, good video even at lower light levels is outstanding on a tripod. You can shoot hand dim light with manual glass for stills, video I think you might need a mono pod at least and a steady hold, even the EVF would help, which I may get later. Its not a high end cannon, but then its (...) and is small and has a good external mic setup and a good EVF if you want it. It can be carried with a light tripod, and a couple of manual lenses, to a site to shoot, and the kit lens in manual is quite good when shooting video.You want a bag camera that can do near high end stills and is ready for video, if you have a mini pod or light tripod, its SO much easeir to carry. I feel confident I can get it done.What does it not have. It cannot use a remote, it has no control mode, cannot be controled by software from a PC, no current remote works. Even the one on Amazon, the Aputure, that says it does. It may work with the Ep2, but not this one. This is irritating. I like a remote for video in studio, but its not a killer. Olypmpus live view is handy in focus assist but really shines on a tripod.  I find manual glass focus fine in low light or shade to focus, on near subjects by hand, but in bright light the LCD washes out. With the Kit lens, for stills, its ok to compose, and its not an issue. I find the E-pL1 on the whole to be easier to focus with manual glass than the 520. Its my top choice in bang for the buck and flexible use, if you can set up a shoot, manual glass is fun, for P and S, the kit is excellent.

Reviews.Title: Not compelling for a "pointer and shooter" or for a DSLR user
Reviews.Author: Cay Horstmann
Reviews.Content: I tried this camera, both with its default lens and a much smaller "pancake" lens. I really wanted to like it, as it seemed an ideal combination of good quality and portability.Yes, the quality is good, but the portability isn't. It's too large and too small.Compared to a point-and-shoot camera, the E-PL1 is HUGE. You can't put it in your pocket. You need to carry a case, which meant for me I wouldn't take it all that often.And when I do carry a case, I might as well take a full-size DSLR camera (such as my Nikon D-5000). The quality is better, and the user interface is far, far superior. The E-PL1 has an LCD display that is unusable in bright light. (You'd need to get the viewfinder which adds more bulk and cost). The controls are flimsy and useless when you can't see the LCD display.I am glad that the camera works great for some people, but I would caution anyone who is considering it to look at it in a store first.

Reviews.Title: A Fun little Camera
Reviews.Author: D. C. Nguyen
Reviews.Content: On the plus side, this camera can be incredibly fun. The built-in art filters can offer some interesting possibilities for some great shots. Furthermore, the Micro 4/3 sensor delivers impressive picture quality. I've been shooting with this camera for a couple of months, and it's hard to get bored of this camera, simply because it offers a good amount of options for your buck.That being said, I feel like this camera is more of a point and shoot rather than a full-blown Mirrorless interchangeable lens camera.  Strictly speaking, the lack of a dedicated shutter speed/exposure dial immediately signals that this camera is MEANT as a novice camera for those who just want good, easy shots. Furthermore, as other reviews have stated, the camera does have a good amount of limitations.Besides the lack of dials, I have two main issues with this camera. First, the autofocus is not as good as it could be. The speed is bearable in good light conditions, but in medium/low light conditions, AF becomes noticeably slower. There is an option for manual focus, but it is not practical in any sense. Also, don't expect to shoot many good nice photos with this camera. The ISO good up to around 500, and if you go past 800, there's a significant increase in noise. I try not to go above 800 at night. I tried to do some street photography with this camera, but it is incredibly difficult if not impossible since I have to drag the shutter speed down to 1/15 or lower (or the camera drags it down for me if I'm in A mode) to compensate for the ISO, thereby making the photo incredibly blurry.However, if you just want a fun little camera that offers a taste of what photography is, then look no further. However, if you're an amateur who knows the basics about photography, then this might not be the camera for you. I've read many reviews stating that there is little difference in terms of image quality between the EP and the EPL. I've yet to confirm this, but for under $300, I believe this camera is worth it.

Reviews.Title: Amazing. Not too complicated, not too simple.
Reviews.Author: Greg
Reviews.Content: I would like to start off on a high note and say that the camera shipped within the hour of ordering it, and arrived 3 days earlier than the estimated delivery time. Anyhow, the camera is beautiful in design and performance. Olympus is a very old brand and has made nothing but quality products ; this is my first Olympus camera to personally own and I couldn't be more pleased. My first camera was the Fujifilm WP Finepix (Don't get me wrong I absolutely adore Fuji and their accomplishments with camera tech. ) and being a sport camera it was only 8MP and did a good job at catching the moment but sacrificing image clarity in the process. When I opened my Pen I hurried to unscrew/undo all the covers and assembled the camera. First picture out of the box was of my sister and her fast food and I was very impressed with the quality. I toyed around with the other features some and this camera shows a lot of potential for some amazing shots. This is a good camera if you're like me and you want a more professional looking camera than just a point and shoot, but don't want the bulk and complexity of a DSLR. I would not recommend this for a photography class unless it was beginner photography or something, if you are going to photograph a wedding opt for a Canon Rebel or a Sony Alpha. However this would be great for a photojournalist or a blogger, it takes amazing pictures and all you have to do is point the lens at the subject! Good camera and I am very pleased.

Reviews.Title: Move up from compact camera
Reviews.Author: Jun
Reviews.Content: I'm very happy with this camera. Still trying to figure out some features but so far I'm a very satisfied costumer. Will buy other lens as soon as I master this camera. Shipping is fast. A+++

Reviews.Title: Very pleased with the camera
Reviews.Author: Jamie
Reviews.Content: I have had the camera for about a month now and it is working wonderfully. The images it takes are great.It is easy to use. I would recommend this camera for those who are looking for something with more features than a point and shoot, but not as complicated as an SLR.

Reviews.Title: Great Buy
Reviews.Author: E C
Reviews.Content: Lets just cut to the chase, this is the best camera buy on Amazon today. At less than $270 it is a steal! I bought this camera and the Panasonic 45-200 for just a few dollars more than a Panasonic GF3 with only one lens. This camera fits between my Panasonic FH20 and Canon 60D.  When I went to Disney World last year I took the FH20 as the D60 with an extra lens in a case was too big and bulky to be in a place with 100,000 people. But the FH20 I felt was too light weight for good steady shots. I now carry PL1 in a small Tamrac belt-pac on day trips and vacations. My 60D with my 70-200mm F4 L lens takes care of the grand kids sporting events while the Fh20 is my daily carry around camera.  IQ from the E-PL1 is wonderful. Crisp. Sharp. This was the bottom line for me. The focus speed is fast enough, the feature set is good enough, and the menu system is fine. I can back off the flash in camera several stops if I need to and I can create a double exposure in camera (when was the last time you saw that feature).  All in all the best bang for the buck you can get in the camera world (IMO).

Reviews.Title: Popping lens cap
Reviews.Author: J. R. BARONE
Reviews.Content: Was in Italy from March 16th to 30th and used my new PEN PL-1 which had many great features and sharp, beautifully detailed pictures.The panorama feature in Scene mode was particularly useful as were the art filters and the easy movie feature. The only disappointment so far has been the lens cap, which was snapped in... it clicked and seemed secured but it often popped off while I was walking. It happened several times. Last day of my trip, went to remove the lens cap and it was already missing. Will write to Olympus. Too bad it isn't attached to a cord, so that it would just dangle away in the breeze and not fall to the street or where ever.

Reviews.Title: Very good but not a DSLR substitute
Reviews.Author: Kanishk Rastogi "Freelenser"
Reviews.Content: A lot has already been written in other reviews about this product. I bought it to evaluate the possibility of replacing my DSLR with this, owing to the small size, lens change capability, and great quality pictures it is supposed to take. Now, don't get me wrong. This camera DOES capture great quality pictures and is lot better than the point-n-shoots. But, it is not a substitute for DSLR. I have a Nikon D60 since last 2.5 yrs and it was very difficult for me to get used to this camera. Exposure control using arrow keys is not easy if you are used to of using the rotating dials.I'd recommend it to those who want to upgrade from point-n-shoots but don't want to spend the money for DSLRs and carry those big cameras. And those who like to use Lensbaby Composer for Micro Four Thirds Digital Cameras with Tilt Transformer and do some creative, artistic photography.

Reviews.Title: Great Small Camera to Carry Around
Reviews.Author: Farzin Shokouh
Reviews.Content: I am a solid PENTAX user. I recommend PENTAX to most people. However, like many, I have always been curious & bemused with OLYMPUS. I could never bring myself to get an OLYMPUS dSLR... until Micro-4Third cameras came out.I loved EP-1,EP-2 shapes but always considered their $ too high until E-PL1 came out. I was quite impressed by OLYMPUS quality. It is a nicely-designed camera. I much prefer its purity of design over PANASONIC Lumix. It is a fun camera to handle, carry & take picture with.Don't expect high FPS or fast auto-focusing from it. It's high ISO is not as good as APS-C size sensors, specially its chroma noise. But compared to serious compact cameras, it is head & shoulder above them in every respect, even in comparison with canon G10/11.Its blue color looks vivid & chic.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!
Reviews.Author: Charles C. Greene
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. Pretty good picture quality. Very portable. Takes multiple lenses which is a big plus. Wish I could get the attachable viewfinder at a reasonable price.

Reviews.Title: I loved it
Reviews.Author: Talina
Reviews.Content: I love this camera, the design is awesome, the quality is great! it's small. I love tha the lens is manual. Definitely one of my favourites, it arrived on time and in good shape.

Reviews.Title: nice
Reviews.Author: Pacificard "alexpuchito"
Reviews.Content: i bought this form my friend the price was good and he feels happy with his camera for mi is ok

Reviews.Title: One Tiny Beef
Reviews.Author: Nick D. "zero2hide"
Reviews.Content: Love this camera, and got a great deal on Amazon since a newer model was introduced.The only issue I have is the outdated charger with its unnecessary cord. A charger with flip pins would have been a perfect match for this compact camera. I am getting increasingly annoyed at this oversight the more I travel with multitudes of cords and chargers!

Reviews.Title: I love this item
Reviews.Author: SEUNGWHAN BAIK
Reviews.Content: as a handy camera ,it is good one. Just light weight and small and easy handling...also pictures are very good quality.Butonly the multi-shooting speed is not so fast as expected

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMERA
Reviews.Author: DAISY C. WATCO
Reviews.Content: I GAVE THIS CAMERA TO MY NIECE AS A GIFT. GOOD ONE AND RIGHT PRICING. IT HAS NICECOLOT TOO.

Reviews.Title: I'll tell you why I love it...
Reviews.Author: Susy V
Reviews.Content: this camera is very useful with it's compact size and affordability.  The images are great; crisp and clean and the look is it is fantastic. I have gotten so many compliments already and I've only had it for a week or something like that... I recommend it. It's beautiful and it is good.

Reviews.Title: Excellent mirrorless camera
Reviews.Author: M. L. Gregory "jhawk1000"
Reviews.Content: This Olympus is great.  I bought it, a couple of batteries and a flash card.  Since then, I have added a 40-150mm lens.  It takes wonderful pictures.  The only con is that the LCD monitor is hard to see in bright light but that is for all cameras without the viewfinder.  Probably will eventually buy the VF-2 viewfinder.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Melanie Thompson "pigsnfish"
Reviews.Content: I'm a point and shoot kind of girl, but my teen girls like what this camera can do.  The 16-year-old took a few kids' senior pictures with it.  They turned out wonderfully.  I, however, still struggle.  There are times when I have it in automatic mode and I take videos instead of pictures.  No one in my family can figure out how/why I can do that, but it happens about 1/2 the time I take pictures.  Definitely worth the money!

Reviews.Title: Good camera for the price
Reviews.Author: William Melcher "Kid"
Reviews.Content: We got this camera to replace our P+S, and it's really good for that.  It's not a DSLR, but we weren't expecting it to be.  I'm happy for the price.  I have a problem focusing sometimes, but that could just be me not knowing the correct setting to put it on.

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: karen feldhousen
Reviews.Content: wonderful camera I love olympus camera's this a great product for out door photos it is great for non photographer's a little hard to understand the digital working. good seller.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera For The Price
Reviews.Author: RJS
Reviews.Content: This was a Christmas gift a family memeber wanted badly.  The camera has performed well.  He is very pleased with it.  The price was right compared to what I've seen it elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Bold
Reviews.Author: emeka
Reviews.Content: Take this camera and make a bold statement on both your photos and your outlook as a potential paparazzo. Seriously, this came is super sharp and gives breath-taking picture quality. It confidently flexes muscles with the other high-prized, top-end cameras.

Reviews.Title: I love it.
Reviews.Author: LUNGX
Reviews.Content: I want to buy a camera with high quality, the DSLR is to heavy for me. I first planed to buy sony NEX-5N, but the price is about 2 times more than E-PL1, however, the picture qualities are not 2 times better than that of E-PL1. So, I bought this one. It's a little bit heavy.

Reviews.Title: Olympus PEN E-PL1
Reviews.Author: Wayne
Reviews.Content: I would like a remote shutter release and a eye level viewfinder. There is an accessory for the latter, but not the former. The camera takes great photos and allows me to use some of my old Pentax K mount lenses, I give it an eight out of ten.

Reviews.Title: great Cam
Reviews.Author: TAROOB BOULOS
Reviews.Content: great cam , fast shipping. after reading reviews and watching reviews i decided to get this great cam for a reasonable price. hope i will improve my skills with this professional one.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Kelly
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. I have used a SLR before, but never used it much because I preferred the convenience of a small point and shoot that would fit in my pocket or diaper bag so I never miss any "cute kid moments".  I would often be disappointed with the quality of the point & shoot pictures when conditions weren't ideal (e.g. low light indoors), so when I heard about the olympus pen and the whole "compact camera system" category of cameras - I was really excited. I went with the PL1 for price, the newer models are significantly more $$ in my opinion and I wasn't convinced it was worth it. This camera takes awesome pictures. It's fast and easy to make adjustments and change settings while you're shooting. I LOVE the art filters.  Only con so far is that it seems a little slow sometimes to process after your snap your picture. No biggie. I'm no photo expert. I just appreciate having some more control and the better quality pictures. Hands down beats any point and shoot. Give it a try, you will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: great camera!
Reviews.Author: risna
Reviews.Content: olympus pen e-pl1 is my favorite EVIL camera.it great on low light, nice image quality with low price :)i bouht it three times.

Reviews.Title: GREAT LITTLE CAMERA.
Reviews.Author: Mr. Samuel W. Sisson
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera after owning an Olympus EP-2 for a year mainly because this one has a built-in pop-up flash. I just wish it focused better at low light levels & I wish it had a built-in viewfinder.

Reviews.Title: amazing camera!
Reviews.Author: J. Gu "truevibesgal2003"
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing camera!  I am in love with it!It takes such clear pictures both indoors and outdoors. Works very well in both regular lighting and low-light WITHOUT flash.I've tried this out on nature, food, models, and events & received lots of compliments.So far I've only played with the auto settings.  I can't wait to shoot manual, I'm sure it'll be even better!

Reviews.Title: Outstanding stabilization, limited controls
Reviews.Author: Micahel Thomas "More of the same, only with m...
Reviews.Content: I'm just floored that that almost no one else has commented on the capabilities of the in-body stabilization in this camera!When I need a highly portable camera I'm primary a GF-1 user, and I purchased a close-out PL-1 body mostly for use with the Olympus M ED 9-18mm f/4.0-5.6 lens in marginal indoor conditions - though I did not have particularly high expectations for this body, as it reviews as having full stop less stabilization that the E-P2.Compared to the Panasonic however, I was hoping to be able to drop back perhaps a 2 stop ISO equivalent to reduce noise.Well, I've been giving it a pretty good workout under low-light conditions and... I'm impressed.*Really* impressed.With this body, and a stationary subject, and poor indoor lighting, in many cases at ISOs as low as 640 I'm able shoot hand held at 1/4 second - even stopped down a bit when I need to, with "acceptable" results under *really* marginal conditions (with a M43 sensor you are always balancing *very* serious compromises in low light, but with the PEN sensor's somewhat better higher ISO performance, plus the stabilization, this body works wonders compared to the GF-1 - I'm getting 3 - 3.5 stops, at least).For example, the uploaded image (above) of the U505 submarine at the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry is straight .jpg  out of the camera, ISO 640,, Oly 9-18mm wide zoom at f/5.6 10mm,... handheld *overhead... at a 1/4 sec exposure(!)Is it perfect?Not by a long shot.Is it *way* better than I have any right to expect?I think so.And it's no fluke, for example out of 8 handheld exposures at that location 6 are of approximately that quality.Now, there is a downside to this body, it's a *lot* of work to set up each shot - a lot of controls that are readily accessible on the GF-1 (let alone most larger-sensor DSLRs) are menu items on the PL1, and it's not a particularly intuitive menu system - it was a *tough* to optimize DOF in that photo.But for a causal user attempting to take pictures under marginal light in the iauto or P modes, that stabilization is going to be golden!And for users who want more control?The PL1 is going back up here on Amazon... I just picked up a *new* E-PL2 here for $299.______________Bottom line: I'm going to give this body five stars - not for me (its' a 3.5-4), but for the user for whom IMO this is the *right* PEN body.

Reviews.Title: Great purchase
Reviews.Author: Andrew Kloster
Reviews.Content: I have had the camera for about a month and it works perfect for me.  Smaller and easier than the full size digital, but still lots of options and features that let you be creative.  Able to set all auto so that I can pass the camera to someone to take our picture with one-touch.  The built in flash is great.  I am very glad I got an extra backup battery.  Next step is to get a wide angle lens attachment?!?

Reviews.Title: Perfect camera for an experienced amateur photographer
Reviews.Author: 4 Kids 2 Exhausted
Reviews.Content: I've had my E-PL1 for over 6 months now, and I am extremely satisfied with it. Where I had been unsatisfied with my previous Fujifilm "prosumer" type camera, which lacked some flexibility necessary for artistically framing shots, this camera offers a great portfolio of options. The E-PL1 captures enough light to be good in low light, it has decent video options, and it has great expandability with the micro four thirds lens system. I now have a 150mm superzoom lens, and I feel like I can take great photos in just about any condition. While it doesn't take as good photos as a big professional grade SLR, it does have all of the important capabilities of a bigger camera while being much lighter and less expensive, and that's the key to its forumla. To me, its a perfect camera for someone who knows their way around a camera, but doesn't take enough pictures to justify a huge investment. A++ product.

Reviews.Title: Now an Olympus fan lol
Reviews.Author: Jeremiah Duncan "Elegant Director"
Reviews.Content: This camera is great and amazing and is such a great product. the art feature is soooo much fun to use it brings colors to a new level. This camera did at first take forever to save files but that is when you use the art feature. the HD is great it's very sturdy and durable. The interchangeable lens is out of this world as a film student it does offer some amazing capabilities and I love this camera I used to hate the brand but this is their future and hopefully it only gets better and better lol.

Reviews.Title: The little camera that could
Reviews.Author: Tango Chaser
Reviews.Content: I must say that this camera saved the day when my main camera was stolen before a shoot. Even though I had seen the Olympus in the store it never really came to mind that I would ever own one.  I was in a remote area and needed to shoot so I bought one and it saved the day.  One person even said "What is that little thing going to do on location?" I said " Big things, Now hand me my flash trigger....Let's rock!"I was also able to use my Nikon glass since I  purchased an adapter. Overall, the shoot was a success. I will keep the Olympus in my kit for sure.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera
Reviews.Author: E-PL1
Reviews.Content: Have really enjoyed this camera so far. It is lightweight and convenient during hefty travels. One can sling it on the shoulder with a water bottle, and not have to complain much. Really nice with the H-H020 20mm pancake lens - Super compact and presents quality images at the same time. By now almost all cameras on market provide quality images, provided the photographer knows the settings. Most have already commented on f stops, aperture and detailed information. What else can a camera offer - that is the question.  It is "the look and the feel".  the classic vintage look makes strangers turn their heads and ask - "Hey what kinda camera you got there?" and feels great to not have answer Canon or Nikon.  This camera Will turn heads. People will love it - I guarantee it. Of course it's great to have a camera that provides good quality images, but it is also the look and feel that inspires one to go out and actually shoot.  No more schlepping a bag full of bricks.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera (with one problem)
Reviews.Author: liz
Reviews.Content: The reason why I got this camera was because this seller was selling it at a reasonable price. The retail price at the official Olympus site is around $600... Which I think is a exorbitant. The shipping was good, made it in time considering the fact that it wasn't a prime-eligible item. I like everything about this camera, from the size to the design and the function. The only problem I have, however, is that the auto-focus is too slow. Takes awhile for it to adjust at certain points.But overall, awesome camera if you don't want to spend two-three hundred more on a DSLR. Cute design too.

Reviews.Title: Too high of expectation from my side
Reviews.Author: Jamster
Reviews.Content: I've done a lot of researches and read a lot of reviews before I finally purchased PEN EPL1 from amazon with the low low price of 395.From what i've read the picture quality is stunning, which set up a really really high bar for me. When i got it and took the pictures, while I do realize a huge improvement to my point&shoot;, however not as "stunning" as most people claim it to be. The pictures are beautiful, but I do see visible flaws at higher ISO levels.Granted I've only had the camera for a short time and have not had much experience on setting the manual specs, or other lenses to play with, this camera does deliver fantastic images (if it wasn't all the reviews i've read about professional qualities and etc i'd be a lot more impressed) and it also records very good HD movies.overall, I think if i tinker with it more i'd have gotten better pic qualities, and i do enjoy the HD movie capture, and as others have pointed out, the mic is mono and picks up a lot of things you don't want in the video, but overall I am very satisfied with my purchase especially at this price.didn't give it a full 5 star, i'd say 4.7

Reviews.Title: Great portable camera at a great price!
Reviews.Author: FJCruiser44
Reviews.Content: I can't say enough great things about this camera.  I was looking for something lightweight and portable to take hiking and keep with me when my DSLR was too much to carry around.  I wanted the ease and portability of a point and shoot but wanted the features and photo quality of a larger camera.  I ran across the E-PL1.  I got the refurbished model which is more affordable than most of the higher end point and shoots.  The camera feels great in your hand and performs very well.  Having the ability to change lenses is a great plus.  I read a lot of reviews about the slow auto-focus but was happy when mine showed up with the updated firmware which addresses the issue.  The art filters add a nice touch which make it kind of fun at times.  The looks of the E-PL1 have a very retro touch to them, which personally I like.  The lack of a viewfinder is kind of a bummer but can be added later for a slightly moderate price.  The only thing that took a little getting used to was the user interface.  It seemed a bit clunky but I have gotten used to it.  Buy this camera,  you won't be disappointed if you're looking for a compact camera with great image quality and tons of features.

Reviews.Title: Olympus PEN EPL1
Reviews.Author: Lauren
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. I was a noob when it came to film and high quality digital photography so this camera has really helped me get started. I am still learning, but I feel much more confident since I have been using this. The image quality is superb at 12.3 megapixels. You have so many effects and lighting options to choose from. I love being able to take it wherever and make a high quality short film as well. :)

Reviews.Title: Fun little camera
Reviews.Author: Michael K. Scherzer "I drank Steve Job's Kool...
Reviews.Content: I have a variety of DSLRs and point and shoot cameras.  This one fits nicely in the middle, it isn't as bulky as my DSLRs (which can get heavy if out sightseeing an entire day) but gives me more control than say a basic P/S camera.  I have been pleased with the image quality and can say that it meets if not slightly exceeds the image quality of the larger sensored Samsung NX100 & NX10 (which I also own and also enjoy).

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: D. DeCillis
Reviews.Content: Purchased this camera for my son's birthday.  He is completely happy with it.  We did a lot of research prior to selecting this product, and so far, it is living up to all the positive reviews we read.  The camera is user-friendly and he has posted some amazing pictures already.

Reviews.Title: great quality
Reviews.Author: Eric Borden
Reviews.Content: I received this camera as a Christmas gift. I do love this camera. It is extremely easy to use and I absolutley love the "old school" style look of this camera. Pros: great pictures, compact, and user friendly. Cons: no view finder (not really a big deal), no dial for shutter and aperature settings. Other than that it truly is a great camera and I have taken some amazing pictures around New England.

Reviews.Title: Solid Camera
Reviews.Author: Cp
Reviews.Content: This is a solid camera that provides a great overall experience. Solid pictures and video. You need to take your time with the camera. The auto-focus setting is not for all occasions. But it has more than enough settings for the advance photographer to use and get the required picture. The auto-focus is a little slow but the manual focusing is great. Not a professional grade camera but it is more than enough for myself(advanced user). If you are a pro get something else, and if you just need a point and shoot this is not for you.

Reviews.Title: This really deserves more than 5 stars.
Reviews.Author: RubyRed
Reviews.Content: Bought as a gift for my sister graduation gift. I'm very pleased with this model, especially since it's user friendly and dumb proof. Wish the waterproof case wasn't just as much as the camera.

Reviews.Title: too many menus
Reviews.Author: ArtW
Reviews.Content: The quality of the photos is very good. But there are two buts: too many menu driven options and not enough external controls. It simply takes too long to make changes. I also feel the optional $200+ electronic view finder is essential if you plan on taking pictures outdoors in the day time. The screen washes out in sunlight, leaving you hoping and wishing that you get the shot you wanted.

Reviews.Title: good camera
Reviews.Author: J. Chang "real user"
Reviews.Content: The Olympus E-PL1 is better than what I expected in low light performance.I compare with my Panasonic LX-3 for the night shots, PL1 out performs the LX-3.The larger image sensor in Olympus gave PL1 edge over other P&S; camera.The only negative is the size of the PL1, it's not pocketable.

Reviews.Title: Great P&S; with changeable lenses
Reviews.Author: that guy with the camera
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera as a secondary travel camera. The lenses are tiny and light, making this system ideal for getting around. It's also much more innocuous than a dSLR, so people don't get as nervous around it. The video is fine, though the MJPEG doesn't seem to transcode as well as h.264. But if not transcoding, the raw video is of good quality. The downside is also the upside. As others have noted before, the menu system is simple, like that of a point and shoot camera. The problem is coming from a dSLR, this is really annoying. The menu system takes a lot to get used to. The extra knobs and buttons on the E-P2 does not make up for the price differential, despite the convenience. The E-PL1 is inexpensive and functional. The large sensor and light lenses make great pictures for this super flexible system. Purchased Panasonic 45-200mm f/4.0-5.6 Lumix G Vario MEGA OIS Zoom Micro Four Thirds Lens for Panasonic and Olympus Micro Four Thirds Cameras soon after and am amazed at the compact nature of the system. With an effective focal length of 400mm, the system gives me extra reach that the kit was unable to provide. The extra reach also brought up another problem with the focus points. While there are plenty of focus points, they're not that fine. Magnifying the display might help this problem, but I have yet to test this in the field. In summary, it's a great camera for the price. Just wish it was more dSLR'y with the controls because I find myself fumbling through the menu system.

Reviews.Title: After 3 months I love this camera
Reviews.Author: Eureka Springs "Eureka Springs"
Reviews.Content: This little camera just inspires from the first day. At long last I now have a digital camera which allows my artistic side to dance. I've already been published locally and around the world simply because I want to shoot photos again. In fact, I can't stop!Don't get exited about shooting in a RAW format unless you own or are ready to spend lot of money on fancy software.I found folks who whine about low res view screen to be wrong... the view screen res is more than adequate for shooting in all kinds of conditions.Still many aspects of this thing I need to explore... so I will list what would make this camera better in hopes someone at Olympus World HQ will consider it.If you don't move the movie button... how about allowing a user to disable it completely in a menu? It's still a pain after months of acclimation.The side door / flap where one connects their mini usb feels very flimsy.. I feel almost certain it's going to break any day now.. it doesn't open all the way from the get go.Please add a pivoting view screen... at least one which flips up from the bottom so one could shoot while holding the camera like an old 2 1/4.The software upgrade improved things noticeably... but please work on the auto focus in low light situations. Photos in low light are fantastic... focus needs to live up to the rest of this cameras capabilities.Can you create a genuine old school pinhole effect... what you call pinhole now is misleading for old timers. Perhaps you should change the name of that effect.The camera should come with a little cord/string connecting the lens cap to the body.. I had to drive over a hundred miles to buy one for 3.00.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: Micah B. Evans "Bohemianman"
Reviews.Content: Ok, so this little Olympus is not for everyone. I have read alot of reviews on this Pen model, and finally drove to my nearest Olympus dealer, and got a hands on review. I really liked it, so I bought it, and have not regreted it. I have been using a Nikon D80 for a while, although a great camera, I am finding it to bulky to carry on trips with me, especially flying. As a matter of fact, I flew out to California, drove up and down the PCH, stopped at several places, took lots of pictures with an Olympus SP-350 point and shoot, with zoom lens, and the pictures came out the same, if not better then my D80's pics. Im serious. So, nowadays, when I travel, I take my SP-350, and I will be taking my new Olympus PEN E-PL1 with me, and will be leaving the D80 behind. Thats all I need now to take great photos. Im amazed by this camera. With the option of buying some lenses,it doesnt get any better then that. I dont take fast action sport photos, or fast moving photos, just landscapes, sunsets, nature, and occasionally people, friends, etc, so the fast shutter speed or lack of it, means very little to me. Its nice, but I can live without it. Anyway, great camera. Im enjoying it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera with a few understandable limits.
Reviews.Author: ManofManyGadgets "Bobbo"
Reviews.Content: The Olympus E-PL1 is a great camera with some limits which may make it a questionable choice for some.  If your looking for the fastest autofocus and huge lens selection, then you should consider the many excellent DSLRs out there.  If your looking for a camera that will outperform most of the compact cameras, then you should consider the E-PL1.  As an entry level micro 4/3s camera it provides excellent value and wonderful IQ.  The video capability adds to the appeal, but its not up to the capability of a good low end camcorder.Much has been said about the lack of control wheels on the E-PL1 versus the E-P1/2.  My personal experience is the control features of the E-PL1 are outstanding and easy to use with a short learning curve.  I was taking pictures immediately after charging the battery.  People stepping up from compact cameras can put the camera in i-Auto and let the camera make the decisions for great pictures under most conditions.  As you get familiar with the user interface, add more control into your picture taking.  People with DSLR experience can use the control features right away as they are quite intuitive.The display can be limiting in direct sunlight.  If you intend to take a lot of pictures outdoors with the sun shining directly onthe display, then consider the excellent EVF for the camera.Coupled with excellent JPEG output most users can use pictures right out of the camera.  Experienced users can use RAW output for post-processing.  The flash works well and I've found it very helpful to add light fill.  It will work out to about 12 feet; further if you increase the ISO to 3200.Anyway, I love my camera and recommend it highly.  My four star rating only applies to the fact that compromises in performance and display screen were made to provide such a compact, high quality camera at an entry level price point.

Reviews.Title: Why No Cable Release?
Reviews.Author: M. Mullins "Book to Book"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the E-PL1 to replace my canon G10 as my every day walk around camera.  The G10, while a wonderful camera, can't be used much beyond ISO 400 because of the noise levels produced by its small sensor.  The E-PL1 exhibits very little noise even at ISO 1600.  The focusing, while slower than a traditional dSLR, is fairly quick and is noticeably quicker than my G10. There are a couple of omissions from the E-PL1 that might make this camera undesirable for a select group of photographers.  First, there is no cable release available for the E-PL1 and, according to the Olympus representative I spoke to, there are no plans to introduce a cable release for this model.  Second, there isn't a focus assist lamp built into the E-PL1 which makes auto focusing in extremely low light impossible.  Finally, if you plan to use the E-PL1 outdoors in direct sunlight get the VF-2 electronic viewfinder; the LCD screen is difficult to see in direct sunlight.  Overall, I'm extremely happy with my E-PL1.  It produces great images in line with my Nikon D90 while being closer in size to my Canon G10.5/10/10 Update:The motor in the 14-42 lens is not powerful enough to use a Cokin P-Series filter system.  I thought I would be able to take advantage of the Cokin filters I already own, however with the Cokin filter holder attached the focus keeps hunting and eventually refuses to work at all; I can still use the Cokin system with the E-PL1 in manual focus mode.

Reviews.Title: E-PL1 a hit
Reviews.Author: Robert A. Franken "Anton 8"
Reviews.Content: I love the E-PL1 from Olympus.  As a former owner of a Mamiya 6mf who swore that he would never move to digital, I have been converted.  I am still learning the camera but it has wonderful features and is both easy to use and very complex.  There are a myriad of options in the custom menu that allow for a ton of flexability.  The single button record for HD video is wonderful, although you have to be careful to shut of the camera when you put it away in the bag least you hit the record button by mistake.

Reviews.Title: Love this Feature-Packed PEN E-PL-1
Reviews.Author: Apis mellifica queen "Barb Bee"
Reviews.Content: The Olympus PEN E-PL1 beats my Olympus Evolt E500 8MP Digital SLR with 14-45mm f/3.5-5.6 & 40-150mm f/3.5-4.5 Zuiko Lenses in every area: clarity & vibrancy of images; weight; ease of use.With the adapter, the PEN-E-PL1 is fully compatible with the Olympus MMF-1 Four Thirds lenses I already have for the E-500.  Purchased the Olympus MMF-1 Four Thirds to Micro Four Thirds Adapter at the same time and ran a test between the two cameras on these three Olympus MMF-1 Four Thirds zoom lenses:  14-45 mm; 40-150 mm; 70-300 mm.  I also compared the PEN E-PL1 kit lens (14-42 mm) and another compact digital camera, the Panasonic Lumix DMC-TZ5K 9MP Digital Camera with 10x Wide Angle MEGA Optical Image Stabilized Zoom (Black) with its 10X Optical Zoom.The PEN E-PL1 came out on top for quality of image.  Have not fully explored all of the settings, but the automatic setting handled everything I tried beautifully.  I have NOT found the lack of the viewfinder (an option on this camera) to be an issue.  The image stabilization feature is superb.  I'm now looking sadly at my E-500 because I love that camera, too, but it has less resolution than the PEN E-PL1, and it is quite heavy - 102.4 ounces vs. 11.2 ounces for the PEN E-PL1 (body).  The 70-300 mm zoom attached to the PEN felt so much lighter than when the E-500 was attached, so I felt I had greater flexibility and freedom in shooting.  Additionally with the PEN's better image stabilization, the images came out very clear in hand-held shots.The range of the kit lens is modest, so I would recommend a secondary lens with higher zoom, especially if you enjoy shooting wildlife or other subjects where you don't want to get too close.  However, the kit lens is great for travel and vacation shots, family photos, and photographing art work (my area).  It is easy to establish a custom white balance so that the true colors of any art are recorded accurately.  The resolution allows for printing images at poster size while maintaining detail.  The other two cameras mentioned in this review can't compete with the level of resolution provided by the Olympus PEN E-PL1.I have owned Olympus cameras since the early 1980's and am a die-hard Olympus fan.

Reviews.Title: PEN magic
Reviews.Author: Jim S.
Reviews.Content: I am a serious amateur photographer and use a Nikon D700 for digital as well as a Leica M7 and Mamiya 6 for film. I used the E-PL1 at an Olympus sponsored event and shot with it all morning. What a blast! Lots of fun, lightweight and very good pictures. I bought two copies for my daughters and have seen some stellar pics from Peru and Glacier as a result. Although the pictures are not quite as good as those from my higher end equipment, the differences won't matter to most people given the high quality results obtained from a very portable camera costing less than $600.

Reviews.Title: This is my DLSR, understand and learn its limitations, utilize its potential.
Reviews.Author: Last of the Bohicans
Reviews.Content: I am an older 35mm guy. My 1st camera was a 110 instamatic and then I got my hands on an upper end polaroid with bellows and a metal slider to put the film in to develop it. Hard to believe. I got my on-the-fly seat of the pants training on aperature, shutter, f-stops, ISO, ASA focal length, etc when I joined the Navy to see the world. I drug AE-1's. K1000sm and other 35mm SLR's thru deserts, jungles (urban and natural) and across the worlds oceans. I learned certain disciplines early, using a tripod and Fuji 100 with a polarizer I produced many, many postcard quality photos, ASA 400 for handheld work and ASA 800 and 1600 for night snapshots. My favorite setup was Yashica FX3 kit. It was full manual like a k1000 with very good 28mm, 50mm and 135 primes. For me it was the ultimate setup for lugging around on my travels. Later on when the family and life's demands a 35mm point and shoot auto became the snapshot camera for family uses. I remember seeing the 1st digital cameras and the writing on the wall. My 1st digital was a 3.2 MP Canon P&S; that took excellent pictures. I purchased it because it had a viewfinder so I could use it in bright sunlight. I became familiar with Chinese manufacturer when the lens mechanism stopped driving the lens and opening the lens. Next was a Samsung  NV10 which impressed me due to its metal body. I loved it, It took good photos. It only had an LCD  and even with a Delkin Hood it was still difficult to compose a shot in bright sunlight. After 3 years and a couple of thousand snapshots the dreaded CCD blue line slow death started. I started to look for a more serious enthusiast camera that could help me seriously move into the digital era and carry on with the serious passion I had in my 35mm SLR days. Enter the E-PL1.  I looked a the E-PL1 and decided the two zoom bundle would fit the bill nicely. I read the positive reviews and like the versatility of the two lenses. In figured the LCD was something I could assimilate to. Let me state now that many will disagree with my assessment of this camera but I stand by my findings and hope to help others of my age and experience make an educated assessment on the purchase this camera and determination of whether it will meet their needs. 1st off plan the price of the VF2 viewfinder with the eyecup if you are serious about composition. The LCD is just too difficult to see in bright sunlight. Plus being an old SLR guy holding the camera closer and firmly is a better discipline. Better yet purchase the VF4, it just a few bucks more. It will not be an upgrade on the E-PL1 but will be  if you decide to upgrade to a 16MP pen such as the E-PL5. After I first purchased this camera and the VF2 viewfinder my niece was having her wedding and asked if I would do the photography. Using just the 14-42mm kit lens I arrived to find that her grandmother had already hired a photographer with Nikon DSLR's. I Shot photos anyhow and in the end many of the photos were better than the hired photographer took. This was handheld and in auto mode. About 50% of the photos were outstanding. The problems with the rest were due to serious backlighting issues causing underexposure of the subject areas. Also there were low light focusing issues where the camera could not focus or was out of focus. Had I understood the manual controls of the camera and been able to be where the photographer had been and using my Tripod the rest of the photos would have been stellar also. It was also a record 108 degrees and the camera functioned fabulously. It did go thru a couple a batteries so invest in extra aftermarket batteries with a wall charger.  I can say with out a doubt you can use this camera at the professional level to shoot weddings if you understand and know how to utilize its potential. After becoming ill for a year and putting my resurgent photography hobby on hold I once again picked up the pen to learn its finer points.  As a Brit once told me "You Yanks are ok but you never bother to read the bloody instructions". As such I highly recommend the E-PL1 for dummies book, it is well worth the money spent on it. Once you read this book and understand the E-PL1's potential it becomes pretty straight forward. From looking at a friends E-PM1 and E-PL3 it will help you navigate and understand other PEN menus also. I can comment or compare the E-PL1 menus compared to the brands because this is my 1st digital camera I have attempted to use manually. The key to using this camera manually is the Super Guide. I find using this operating the camera manually is very straight forward.  At the time I purchased this camera I had no idea that you could purchase adapters to utilize legacy lenses. My biggest complaint with digital camera systems is the staggering cost of good prime lenses which is why I purchased with the 2 zoom bundle. I was overcome with joy as I had a large collection of K-mount bodies and lenses. I have selected a new Sigma 28-85mm I had in new condition in the box.  a 28mm f 1.8 SMC-A Pentax, 50mm 1F1.2 SMC-M Pentax, and an excellent , super sharp new in the box Vivitar 135mm Series 1. These I already had. I purchased a used in new condition excellent Rokinon 70-200mm zoom for 20 bucks. The results with these legacy lenses have been excellent. Being an older person to me digital photos have what I call a digital look. This may be hard for some to understand but people my age reading this they will understand. It is like listening to stereo music in the old days with the old Marantz, Sansui, Fisher ball bearing analog stereo receivers, the digitally processed stereos sounded digital. To my old eyes the photos look digital and the legacy lenses make it look more film-like. While on the subject of using these legacy lenses remember that if you us IS make sure you set the focal length for the lens and figure in the crop factor, if not you will be working against yourself. If you are using a legacy zoom this will need to be changed as you vary the focal length. If you plan on changing focal lengths a lot you might fare better if you shut the IS off. Also remember that with any lens you use shut the IS off when using a tripod.  I am of the opinion that if you are using the IS with legacy lenses and the focal length is incorrect the IS circuitry will be stressed because it will be constantly hunting for a solution it cannot achieve due to be fed incorrect data. The 4/3 lenses the focal length is fed to the body automatically thru the electrical contacts. Also make sure you figure in the crop factor. Of course these changes can be done reasonably fast using the super guide. Other anomalies to deal with when using legacy lenses with using adapters is that the legacy lenses put a lot of weight on the camera body when using a tripod. I was able to get an adapter on Amazon that has the tripod mount on the adapter so you can put the weight on the adapter and not the camera body.  This is also beneficial in that you have to remove the camera off the tripod mount to change the battery or memory as they are accessed from the bottom of the camera. By mounting on the adapter you avoid this. The tripod mount capable legacy adapter is highly recommended. Also when using legacy adapters set the sharpness control to +1 on primes and +2 on zooms as a general rule for best focusing results. Experiment with each legacy lense to finds its sweet spot. Others have told me that you can process this out later but I disagree, the better it is going in the better it will be later. The sharpness setting is electronically varying the sensor distance from the legacy lens helping it achieve sharper focus. This setting is also easily accessed with the Super Guide.  After putting this together I decide I wanted to have a spare body so I found a used purchased as reconditioned with a K-mount adapter and a  50mm f2.0 SMC-M. After getting it home and playing with I found later after putting my 14-42 kit lens on it that it would not auto-focus nor would it focus manually. I put the lens on my other E-PL1  and it would focus fine. I have tried to find a setting to resolve this but I have been unable to find a setting that can be changed or reset to remedy this and it has the 1.1 firmware. So if some knows of something I overlooked by all means provide me a comment. This is unfortunate because my biggest complaint is with the 4/3  is the crop factor I do not have a good manual 28mm wide angle. I was planning on having to use the 14-42 kit lense as my 28mm wide angle and I only have 1 body that can use it. Plus I would prefer something that produced something more film looking. I was able to locate a Vivitar labeled Samyang 17-28mm legacy zoom. This lens has average reviews but with the sharpness set to 2 it is bitingly sharp but it only crops out to 34-56 and I would prefer a good 28mm  equivalent prime. Zenit produces a 16mm fisheye with funky film plane side screw in color filters. If the Russians at Zenit are smart and read this they would make 12, 14, 16, 18, and 19mm 35 manual primes modelled from this existing 16mm 35mm fisheye to fit the new generation crop sensor digital cameras. They are already tooled up to make M42 and K-mounts and they would sell like hotcakes provide they thread it to take filters from the front side and they keep the price around 150 to 200 bucks . They are too many legacy lenses of other focal lengths to make producing those focal, lengths profitable. On the subject of kit lenses they are sharper at there lower 14 and 40mm focal lengths. On all the legacy lenses I use Polarizing filters and I find the Agfa being the better ones of the lower end ones. They use Japanese glass and pass the thump test I learned in my film days. The better filters will produce a crisp distinct tink sound when thumped with your finger. Lesser quality ones produce a dull thud. There are complaints of these and other filters ghosting. On this subject when using legacy lenses use a rubber adjustable lense hood because digital lenses have more coating on them because the silvery shiny sensor will reflect light back into the lense and the legacy are more prone to frontal glare also.  As for video I did not use it for that nor do I know what to compare it to. But from what I  have played with so far  it is suitable for any videos I may want to make and yes the button is too easy to activate and I have already acquired a few surprise videos. But I changed the function of this button to change the camera  to manual focus mode and  I have changed the function to RAW+JPEG or Preview or Face Detection off.  On the Face Detection mode issue the autofocus seems to be quicker and surer if it is off when not actually looking for faces. I purchased the audio mike adapter to enhance the resale value one day but haven't used it. When using legacy lenses you can select scene modes and set to Manual focus and then manually focus and adjust the aperature to get  the proper exposure but you must have the liveboost off that varies the LCD intensity and actually works better with the EVF. I have found the results produced by the scene modes excellent and I like being able to use legacy lenses with the Scene and Art Modes.  So my final verdict on the E-PL1? Autofocus issues?, yes the autofocus does not function well in low light. If you want a camera for fast action this is not for you. The JPEGS from this camera are excellent but I shoot RAW + JPEG  Large SF on the stills I use this for because I want to become knowledgeable at processing JPEGS and TIFF files.  I have read from others posting reviews that this is an excellent digital back for legacy lenses. I think this hits the nail right on the head. This is a camera that can wear many hats. With a 37mm and optical viewfinder it can be a rangefinder type street camera. with the 15mm lens cap lens a convienant  P&S; and with the EVF and adapters a DLSR using economical excellent legacy lenses.  The body has an excellent grip in my opinion. So for me it is an excellent camera for stills which is what I will use it for. For those wanting a camera for action shots look elsewhere. But with the EVF and legacy adapters  and lenses it is the size of a DLSR so knowing what I know I know now I probably would opt for a Pentax DLSR with the larger sensor and 1.5 crop factor and in body IS, also maybe a Sony using my K-mounts with adapters as it hs in body IS I believe. But for now I'm committed and am pleased with my photos which is what matters. As my shills grow and progress I will problably keep the pen system and maybe a E-PL5 with a 37mm and optical viewfinder to go with what I already have. But I do see a 24mp K3 Pentax in my future. I want to thank others who have posted on this camera for all the great and useful info they provided.

Reviews.Title: good choice
Reviews.Author: M. Swarr
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! After several point and shoots that quit or declined in quality after a year or two, I was ready for something more dependable. I am by no means an experienced photographer, so I didn't think I was ready for a full-fledged DSLR. Thank goodness I settled on this darling.There are plenty of settings and photo options to keep me busy, and with all the selections, it is almost impossible to take a bad photo. Needless to say, that after 5 years of bad cameras and 2 years with no camera at all, I feel like I couldn't have wound up with a better one.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera, great price
Reviews.Author: nate
Reviews.Content: Got this for work, needed better quality shots but don't want to lug around a DSLR.  Close up shots are INCREDIBLE!!

Reviews.Title: So Far So Good
Reviews.Author: Rich P
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for the specific purpose of photographing my original paintings for reproduction. I am not by any means a professional photographer so there has been a learning curve but so far the camera has preformed as well as expected. My purchase was based on the reviews of other owners and suggestions from camera magazine articles.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Emily
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend I have been looking for a camera for a few months and saw the great reviews and the great price and do not regret jumping on it! The camera takes amazing photos and has a lot of different settings and even tips for your photo subject. If you are looking for a camera with a large zoom though dont get this. Its for shorter range photos but we knew that going it. I highly recommend this camera!

Reviews.Title: I love this camera!
Reviews.Author: Bo
Reviews.Content: I was looking for something smaller but with slr quality. I found it and more with this camera. I know people with bulkier and more expensive slr cameras and I am way more pleased with my photos and the simplicity of the Olympus Pen E-PL1. I have had it for about a month now and haven't had any issues. I love the extra art settings this camera offers too. I would recommend this camera to anyone!!!

Reviews.Title: A very capable camera
Reviews.Author: Elliot Bernstein
Reviews.Content: I am a part time pro and bought this camera for my personal 'fun' use.  I wanted a small, light camera that was capable of delivering great pictures. It has not disappointed me.  Image quality is as promised and as good as any DSLR.  Autofocus is accurate and adequate for most shooting situations except where the subject is moving towards or away from you, which is a common problem with most cameras of any type except higher end DSLRs.  High ISO performance is excellent and significantly better than all P&S; cameras, even then high end ones.  I bought (and returned) one of the newer Lumix cameras because image quality above ISO 400 was not acceptable to me.  The E-PL1's IQ at ISO 1600 is amazing.The E-PL1 is not a perfect camera but it sure comes close.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera
Reviews.Author: J. Gutz
Reviews.Content: Well i got my Pen yesterday and all i can say is WOW the shots are so amazing after hearing all ther reviews about the focus and what not i updated the new firmware so i dont see any lag at all maybe being in a really dark place but i havent encountered that yet..coming from a ton of point and shoot cameras this is a major upgrade for me the pics are just unbeliveable like i said im not a pro but just someone who love to take nice pics everwhere i go and the cameras is not big at all i thought it was going to be bulky no way took about 200 inside shots and this is were alot of pont and shoots have failed me in the past the Epl1 excelled......im glad i did my homework and read many reviews some being totally negative but the majority were right this cameras i simply outstanding....

Reviews.Title: Good for photo novice who wants to learn
Reviews.Author: A. Whitney
Reviews.Content: After several point & shoots  wanted to upgrade to a better quality camera, but was worried that I would get one that was way beyond my abilities. This camera seemed like a good compromise. I have only had it for a few weeks, but I have been experimenting a lot with it. With point/shoot cameras there wasn't much to do, so I only used them when needed. The variety of controls on this camera inspires me to mess around with it a lot more. But when I need to snap a shot, the automatic settings make it easy. I look forward to being able to get new lenses for it when I improve my photo abilities. I can see what others are saying about the camera body being so small that larger lenses may make it harder to control/balance. It is a light, small camera that looks like a point/shoot with a lens added to it.What I like: The varying degrees of automatic shooting-> manual shooting. I can use it totally automatic, or choose to only set the aperture or shutter speed manually, or go totally manual. I think this will be quite helpful with learning. The ability to change lenses will come in handy later in my use of the camera. The video looks pretty good. Even though I have a Mac, I have no problem downloading images from the camera via the USB cable. The flash isn't exceptionally powerful, but does a good job. I dig the old-style look of the camera in champagne gold, which really just looks like textured aluminum. The custom settings make it easy to do cool effects like double-exposure and panoramic photos. Until I learn how to use the manual setting better, I was able to use the fireworks and candlelight settings to take some cool shots by a bonfire.What I don't like: I'd prefer an actual wheel to cycle through controls rather than the buttons, since I found myself accidentally pushing the buttons when taking shots. The stock camera only has the screen for seeing your shot, but it makes it hard to truly see the image in the sun. But the camera + viewfinder was out of my budget. The locking lens makes it hard to snap a shot quickly if the camera is put away. I find that the time for an image to save makes it difficult to shoot images quickly. Mind you, it does have the setting for taking multiple shots in bursts, but sometimes you need to just shoot another shot quickly, such as when you are taking a photo of a pet or a child & they aren't "posing."Overall, I think this camera will be a great aid to improving my technique, and will deliver some great quality images along the way.

Reviews.Title: The E-PL1 is the perfect Assistant SLR. (or is it Assistant to the SLR :)
Reviews.Author: Manish Bhatia
Reviews.Content: I spent several months on trying different cameras to co-reside with my trusty Kodak Z712 IS that was still producing wonderful pictures at a very high success rate. During the process I also learnt a lot about them and having kids, I was very interested in the quality aspect of the images since I did not want to lose the well, Kodak moments :)Just like most consumer electronics, everybody has different needs. I learnt that you cannot have everything in one camera because if you did, the industry would shut down and quit making any more upgrades.Here are some key things that I learnt that I want to share with people scratching their heads between cameras and SLRs vs P&S.;1)  It is ALL about the sensor. NO MATTER what P&S; you get, no matter what is built around it (touchscreen, front screen, a tank (G-10), uber zoom lens, you will ALWAYS be stuck with a small sensor compared to SLRs and therefore always have a liability in low light and high ISO pictures.You need to look at sensors like Dart Boards. Bear with me, I am trying to clarify this. Imagine you have two dartboards that you are aiming at. One is a much smaller dartboard where the circles of quality (points) are pretty small and one which is 7-8X times the size of the first dartboard with correspondingly larger circles including an easier to hit Bullseye (the best picture).The odds of you hitting the bullseye and high points on the second board will always be higher no matter how much you try to screw up. (auto modes). On the smaller board, you can still hit the bullseye but the chances are much lower UNLESS you shoot 50 darts at it (multi shot modes) and hope one sticks OR you are one of the best dart throwers in the business who knows all about wind speeds and trajectories and somehow manage to squeeze a high point shot frequently.So there you go. Either you need to be really good at the photo process (and speed of decision is critical sometimes at the perfect moment) or you simply take a high volume of shots and utilize the percentage of good to great shots you can get out of the bunch. Do not try to compare some random shot from a P&S; to a SLR because it just meant you happened to hit the bullseye somehow and not that they are equal by any means. SLRs will CONSISTENTLY out perform a P&S; for HQ pics.2) Portability - The best camera is the one with you. Unfortunately that means the cell phone for most people. However, the E-PL1 gives you hope to salvage the memories at a formal lunch or a party where unobtrusiveness is critical and you dont want to stick a huge SLR in someone's face. The kit lens is small, not very small but enough to avoid nervous glances anytime you try to click. Stick the pancake 20 mm Lumix Lens and they won't know what hit them. I consider SLRs to be EVENT based items where you have to plan to take them to a birthday function, wedding etc and its OK to have a piece of luggage with you while everyone else use a compact. The E-PL1 would make an Excellent Assistant SLR. (or is it Assistant to the SLR :)3) Price - while the price is reasonable for the basic lens kit it is not cheap and I agonized over the 20 mm LUMIX lens and finally got it since it is simply a match made for the EPL1 form factor with a huge low light advantage. However, you need to remember that a lot of P&S; lose value a lot quicker than SLRs that will take good pics no matter the date of manufacture. Since this is a new technology still evolving, your return on investment should be very good for this camera since it has all the necesssary features in it. (the next one could have a view finder, doubt it since the whole size thing would be compromised), there is already flash and high MP to take you through several years (get an accidental warranty and you might be set for much beyind in case something should happen to your camera and it is discontinued)4) Megapixels are a very misunderstood concept. On a P&S;, the higher the MP the more noise and issues at high ISO you will have since the PIXEL DENSITY is reduced (MP/Sensor size). That is why my 7 MP Kodak stays awesome for regular prints upto 8x10 since it does not falsely advertise its capabilities. A 12 MP on a small sensor on a P&S; is asking for trouble. The key in my (very limited) experience is that you need to use the Flash as little as possible and use natural light and proper framing and placement with minimal zoom (use your legs). As such high ISO usability is very important to get at least a nice 8x10 print if desired, 4x6 would be more common.The E-PL1 is fantastic at high ISOs and pictures are not burnt out by the flash5) Software/Editing is the main element of good digital photography and I am still a novice on this one so it is all the more critcal for me to have good art option ON BOARD the camera (stitching, diorama, sepia etc) This makes it a lot easier to see the after effect of the shot before it happens and saves you time later on the PC.RAW files while large and not commonly used by the average consumer are good to save for the important pics as a DIGITAL NEGATIVE if nothing else.So, after the long expose, here is the rundown.I ended up keeping the camera. I like my toys cheap and usable so its never easy for me to make a major purchase regardless if I have the money.I did not miss the view finder as much as I thought I would.Pictures are consistently good and the Olympus JPEG engine is awesome.I got the 20mm LUMIX pancake lens and use the flash as little as possibleThe art filters are great. The Sepia is a nicer type not the washed out brown pics like others.The cool/wow factor is high and will remain as such for the near future since its a new type of technology (not just model)Auto focus for the kit lens was improved with the firware upgrade but still not as speedy as you would likeThe 20 mm lens on the other hand.....This camera will need work for very young kids and pets that don't work as well with you for posing. 3-4 yr olds and above will be fine and there are burst options/modes you can play with to utilize the dart board theory to take multi-pics in those situations.Get a tripod for shots that you can plan out like in a glamor shop (makes you look cool and like a pro) and minimizes errors and blurs. Essential for night and fireworks etc. The 20 MM will give you some extra  help and onboard Image Stabilization will help as well on any lens.Oh, and I am actually having fun taking pics now. I am taking more random pics of my kids and ending up framing even the unplanned poses. My facebook albums are like a gallery now for even regular pics.

There was a school performance the week that I got it so I tried it out. The results were not very good.While I hadn't considered a micro 4/3 camera, I happened to see this on sale. I also found the 40-150 lens .Olympus M.Zuiko 40-150mm f/4.0-5.6 R Micro ED Digital Zoom Lens (Black)on sale and all together the kit cost about the same as the higher end "superzooms" that I thought were what I was going to end up buyingA little reading on the web and a conversation with a guy at a camera shop convinced me that the image quality would be better with this camera so the only question was the zoom.I've now used this camera at the zoo and at a performance and am very happy with the results.So if you've ended up here as someone considering a superzoom, this camera with an additional lens may be an option. I've never had the highest end superzooms but this definitely beats the "travel zoom" that I had for about a week.One caveat, if you're not getting a good deal on this camera, it may make sense to look at DSLR's because I don't think the smaller size of this is such a big deal. That said, I do like the size and also the look of this camera.I'm shooting a lot more pictures with this thing and having lots of fun with it.
